Courteous service; very tight eating area. People next to me were eating hungrily. The King of Falafel on bush/divisadero is still my Favorite maker of those veggie falafels.
author: Bert K.

description: I never/rarely make it out to SF unless its for a Giants game... But prior to hitting movie in the park with the BFF- we hit up this place for seriously THE BEST lamb schwerma I have ever come in contact with. HUGE portion. Delicious. Spicy. Tender meat. Fresh ingredients. Topped it off with a side of falafels and we were golden! Amazing and worth a trip to SF. I've been craving it ever since !!
author: Melissa K.

description: Love the lamb shawerma - tender with a kick! The Athens burger is a good twist on a traditional burger (wrap with cucumber), and moist & tasty. Place is small, so not really a sit down w/ friends.
author: Stan L.

description:
Here's what I saw/heard while waiting outside for my buddy to arrive:
- Couple walking with one saying to the other, "This place serves the best greek food in the city."
- Dog begging for a piece of that shawarma... and winning.
- Cat in a coat in a stroller with 2pac blasting from the rear.  Man pushing said stroller.
- Another group walking by, "What smells so good?"
- "Order the chicken shawarma.  These guys are experts.  They're the best."
- "Mmmmm."

The last one was from me and my friend after finally sitting down for dinner.  So good!
author: Linda T.

description:
My favorite Shawerma place in SF! The guys here are awesome and can always be counted on making great food at a very good price. They either do Lamb shawerma or chicken depending on the day (never both) and also make falafel (I'm partial to my mom's falafel, which is hands down the best falafel i've had) which is pretty good.

It's a shame I don't eat here more often, but when I crave that comfort food that only some spit roasted shawerma can fix you better believe I'm going to Truly Mediterranean.
author: Mike K.

description:
Friendly. Tasty. Close to home.

So what's the problem? At $10 for a wrap, Truly Mediterranean is charging a few bucks more than the going rate for chicken kebab in lavash goodness. Not helping matters was the extra charge for hummus even though I didn't want tzatziki. No amount of smiles and thank yous overcomes that lack of an even trade.

I've definitely experienced better.
author: Jason B.

description: I love this place! I'm obsessed with their falafel wrap! I eat there a few times a month, and it's always consistently good. :)
author: Michelle C.

description: Not really impressed. It's definitely busy and made to order, but it was expensive an not that great. They grill the lamb schwarma after they slice it off the spit, which in my opinion dries it out. The lavash bread was too dry after being grilled. NYC is def better and cheaper. No repeat for me.
author: Vanessa K.

description: The lamb shawerma - recommended in 7x7 for the Big Eat - is definitely delicious.  It may be pricey, at $9.30, but worth it.  Make sure not to stop by on Tuesdays or Fridays because they don't serve lamb on those days.
author: Chad S.

description: Lamb shawarma is amazing. Get it spicy with extra tahini sauce. Some days don't serve lamb so look out for that
author: J D.

description:
Sigh...this is one of the places I really miss now since I've been away from the city for far too long.  

Dear Chicken Shawarma, I miss you and your awesome, and for how well you went with Orangina and filled me up for cheap. I can still smell you in my dreams.

Much love,
-Pining in Portland
author: Michelle C.

description:
hummus, falafel, tabuli and fresh veggies I'm there. I'm not really a fan of lamb so the chicken or falafel are better chooses. Kinda expensive because all the sides cost extra. 

Sitting outside is fun until a homeless person reeking of urine decided to stop by and have a convo.
author: Jade W.

description:
Came here on December 27, 2011.... Taking me this long to finish the review so sorry ;-)

This is basically a Dive Mediterranean place which has some decent Chicken Sharma.  We got some wraps to go and I don't remember the price but the Chicken Sharma was definitely worth it. 

Probably won't go back as it's more a blue collar type place but their food was alright.
author: Arthur Z.

description:
I have been a fan for over 10 years. I had lunch here the other day with a friend and realized it has been too long since I have enjoyed their falafel.
The deluxe falafel is cooked to perfection with lots of veggies and ask for the hot sauce to add a spicy punch to the meal.
Be sure to be hungry, these wraps are a meal!
author: Curtis H.

description:
Let's keep it short.  Everything that could be said, has been said.

Best falafel I have ever had.  
Get the Falafel Deluxe. 
If you are claustrophobic, you might want to go somewhere else.  
Oh so delicious.
author: Nick C.

description: We got a lamb shawarma and baba ganoush. The shawarma was decent, the baba ganoush was below average.
author: Chandrika G.

description:
I'm truly stumped.

I've heard almost universal rave reviews for this place, and as a HUGE (vegetarian) lover of Mediterranean food, I couldn't wait to try the falafel.

Apparently I needed to get the Deluxe, because judging by the other reviews, the eggplant is what "makes" it. Otherwise? I found my regular falafel wrap very dry... as though it needed twice as much tahini (then again, maybe that's because the sauce seemed to get all over my HANDS instead of my mouth). Either way, I thought the service was great - completely friendly and quick - and the wrap is large enough to last me two meals!

I'm going to give you another chance, Truly Mediterranean... here's hoping your eggplant is divine!
author: Sam S.

description:
Great Felafel Wraps.. this place hits the spot for that Mediterranean craving.

Downside is that the ingredients aren't always fresh (i.e. might have been sitting out a while).
author: Ayall S.

description: a quality of delux falfell that just never ever dips below 5 stars- 20 years running.
author: Ryan L.

description:
One of our go-to place when we're in need of a quick food. It's just 5-10 minutes away from our house and they always prepare the take-out order very quickly.

The falafel deserves all the fame it's getting. It's crispy and delicious. We always get the Mediterranean combo plate as it has a little bit of everything. The Baba Ghannouj (Eggplant paste) is great, as well as the hummus.

My personal favorite is the lamb shawerma though; it's the Greek's answer to burrito and I love lamb. It's spiced well and the hot sauce is amazing.
author: Handoyo S.

description: My favourite mediterranean spot in the Mission. The only thing is I only come here for the lamb. They switch off between lamb and chicken depending on the day, and I feel they marinate them both the same and the chicken suffers slightly.
author: Bantu Z.

description:
I love hole-in-the-walls. Their falafel is something worth trying.

I love their chicken shwarma. JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: My friends and I went here on 4-13-14 9:30pm'sh.  We ordered the lamb shawerma, it's delicious/most, $9'sh each.  I wanted the chicken shawerma (but only available on tuesdays+fridays). My friend ordered the baklava (Mediterranean pastry), flaky/sweet.
author: Jer W.

description: Not only do they have by far the best wraps and falafel that I've tasted anywhere, but the gentleman behind the counter (I assume he's the owner but I've never verified) recognizes me and my wife every time we go (which is literally only once a year for the past 10 years) and always gives our kids little extras to munch on.  Great food, great service.  What else do you need?
author: Greg M.

description:
Being new to Mediterranean food, I was hesitant to go here at first.  However, after trying the lamb shawerma, my boyfriend and I love this place!!  We always get the shawerma, at least once a week.  I prefer it with chicken, but it's only served Tuesdays and Fridays, but thats no big deal.  I kind of like it, it makes it more special.  I have my special "Tuseday Night Chicken Shawerma" haha.  They serve lamb all other days of the week.  
It's never too packed (even though it can feel like it because the place is so tiny.  No complaints though), and everyone who works there is super friendly and helpful, if you have questions.  The food is always hot and delicious, the perfect comfort food after a long day.
author: Caitlin D.

description:
There's too many reviews for this place. I feel redundant but I'm going to document that I ate here anyway!

Ordered a chicken shawarma (because they don't have lamb on Fridays! WHY!? And also on another day but I forget which). TASTY, mostly due to the grilled tomatoes and eggplant I think. The Mediterranean Plate was pretty legit (for the veg-fans out there). I mooched some of the falafel and it was yums. I'll probably bump it up a star after i experience the lamb.

Ordering and receiving the foods was pretty quick and painless, even with a line nearly out the door on a Friday night. Hi5!
author: Jennifer N.

description: Hands down by far the best Chicken Shawarma in the world!! My friends and I would drive from San Mateo to the city, and then drive around the place in circles for like an hour just to find parking for them Shawarmas....oh Snap!! Hot damn!! The best I tell ya!
author: antoinette c.

description: Loved this. Tried the lamb and falafel wraps and both were excellent. Also tried the plate which was delicious. The hot sauce is good. The garlic mint yogurt drink was cool and good but more garlicky than the ones you get in the Middle East. The pistachio baklava were fresh tasting and very good- not so sweet that your tongue burns. The only thing I wish I got were some beets!!! I guess you have to ask for them???
author: Piper W.

description:
So, I've just started the 2010 Big Eat List in SF. Yeah, i know the year is over, but I already knocked out 4 in 2 days :O

We ordered the lamb schawerma and a falafel just cause we were there anyway.  The lamb schawerma is the item on the 100 list.  I kind of expected a little more since it made the list and so in that sense, I was a little disappointed.  But, if I just ate it with no preconception, I'd give it a four star.  

There was a lotttt of meat in it and the sauce was good, but nothing particularly great enough to be on the list.  I know schawermas and gyros are different but I'd rather eat a gyro from ayola's.
author: Anna C.

description:
BALLS!!!!

The Deluxe Falafel Schawerma makes me want to become a vegetarian.  What's meat? 

What attracted me to this place was actually the meat roasting in the window as you walk down 16th St. And I love meat.  So I went in and luckily, I had a friend with me so we ordered one Deluxe and one Chicken shawerma.  Surprisingly the chicken one was kinda dry but that's okay because the Deluxe makes up for it! This place seriously makes the best falafel balls I've ever had. I bring everyone here to try them. And add eggplant and potatoes YUMMM

Each Shawerma is sharable but easily capable of being devoured. he perfect combo for me is the half a Deluxe and half a side of Tabouleh.  Bomb dot com dinner right there! I just had one tonight...and I still want one tomorrow.

The staff is friendly and service is quick.  Prices are alright...$8/wrap...  Sucks that there's very minimal seating and not a good place for a "catch up" meal with friends.  But I'm willing to sacrifice! 

BALLS!!!!
author: Helen V.

description:
After departing the Upper Haight when their building was torn down for new condos, I kinda forgot about this place. The wait for Ti Couz was excessive and I looked across the street and was like "Hey, that's the place I used to go a few times a week when I lived on the Panhandle!"

Went over and grabbed a lamb schawerma with some eggplant. Juicy, well seasoned lamb, crispy lavash from grilling post assembly. Ahh, just like I remember. Need to come back when I'm in the area.
author: Andrew C.

description: Their lamb shawarma is amazing. It has so much meat in it that it's hard to finish, even if you're hungry. Price-wise, it's a little expensive, but the service you get (with the hilarious owner, and all) is great. Not much in the way of sitting area, so it may be best you just take it home with you.
author: Andrew L.

description: i'm far from a connoisseur of mediterranean food but even i could tell the hummus and falafel were special!  i even loved the mediterranean sampler and i don't usually like tabbouleh. i can't rave though because i got a botched family style order and i ended up getting a side of dry, flavorless lamb shawerma with pita. i can't speak to how the wraps usually taste, but it was the same meat which makes me think the meats may have been overhyped.
author: Cailin H.

description:
A small hole in the wall place, but worth a taste.

I went here at night with a couple friends. We all had ordered the lamb shawerma. At $8 it's a bit pricey. However, the wrap is rather big and the lamb was very juicy and tasty. I wish it was more spicy though.

If you're gonna get the lamb be aware that they don't serve it on Tuesday and Friday. On those days they serve the chicken shawerma instead.
author: Andrew C.

description: came here hoping for lamb shwarma...unfortunately, i wasn't able to try it since they only had chicken available that day. hummus was good. I'd go back to try the lamb. The chicken shwarma could have used more tahini....kinda dry.
author: Cecilia B.

description:
Stopped by here just the other night in between a party looking for a quick bite.

There was a small line when entering the 10x20 room. The two before me quickly made their order and i was asked of mine right after. I got a lamb wrap spicy (only because everyone on yelp said go spicy)

It was pretty good, my only gripe is the gristle/fat pieces in the lamb. I'm not a fan, i suppose it's great for flavor, but who wants to chew on that?

it's about 10 bucks for the lamb wrap. I left the change for tip.

Quick service, toasted and good.
author: N S.

description: Best shawrma in the Bay Area it's really good  juicy they don't put lattice all meat tahini sauce best Mediterranean food and price is very fair for the portion and the quality
author: Basel A.

description:
3 letters in meh = 3 stars.

better than a $9 turkey sandwich but not better than a $5 turkey sandwich.
author: Alex T.

description:
I tried shawerma for the first time every today.  Me and a buddy of mine had to after watching "The Averngers".   I had the lamb shawerma with a side of hummus.  The shawerma wrap was amazing.  It was very tasty and juicy.  The hummus was also very very good.  I am a huge hummus fan, and this hummus is GOOD.

I would highly recommend this place to anyone!  Parking kinda sucks but that goes with just about anywhere in the city.  The staff were all friendly and the food was made up fast.  I will definitely go again.
author: David C.

description:
Drunken nights back in the mid-90s... chilly Sunday walks from Delores Park... a quick bite to eat before hopping on the 22... This place is part of the tapestry of my life in San Francisco. 

In May 2007 I returned to my beloved hole-in-the-wall to be greeted with the familiar aromas and flavors I dream about when I'm away. One shawerma just isn't enough. I always buy two so I can eat one on the way home and have another for later.

I was disappointed to not have my favorite Lamb Shawerma but the chicken was pretty good too. Just thinking about this place and I'm ready to fly back to San Francisco and have another.
author: Allison J.

description: The wrap is huge but the prices match it. We got the chicken so I have to come back for the lamb one. They like their onions which is not a problem with me but the wrap is kinda of dry. I wish there was the white sauce that they put in the halal food in NY. The flavor was good but nothing to scream about. I guess there will be a repeat to finish the list.
author: Eve C.

description:
Came here on a lunch break with my coworker. The place is small without a sign sticking out. We walked passed it twice and barely saw it. We had to refer to our phone maps twice just to make sure we were on the right block!

The wraps are big. I got a lamb shawarma. Theres lots of meat in it and lots of onions.... Be sure to have a piece of gum ready after! I think I ate it too slowly that the meat started getting cold, hard, an all the fat was showing.... I stopped eating it and packaged it up to reheat at home. 

$9.09 with tax included.
author: Rosanne L.

description:
I love this place, I actually drove couple of times from San Jose to San Francisco just to eat there and drive back, haha

Their lamb shawerma is the best thing to get there and there flafel is pretty good as well. If your craving good shawerma or good flafel just drop by and try it.
author: Rami A.

description: Came here with an online deal, ordered spicy lamb shawerma & hummus. It was good but could be much better. I was going to get the taboula but decided not to when I saw how small the container was for the price, I also saw there wasn't much tomato or cucumber- parsley and bulgur doesnt equal taboula. As for the hummus it was good- a little pricey but I've gotten use to that in San Francisco. The Shawerma was okay. I've been spoiled with the authentic stuff and places that have come close to over sea's on the East Coast. For being in a big city and on the West Coast I'd give this a B-. It has good flavor but tastes like something I could make at home and was more like a fajita than the shawerma I usually eat. It was also pricey for just a sandwich. Im use to $6-7 for shawerma with fries or a side. Close to $10 for just a sandwich that wasn't fully loaded and no sides, I wouldn't order this without an online deal.
author: Bint H.

description:
Falafel deluxe wrap is comparable to the size of an elfaro burrito.

The lamb schwermas don't come with potato and eggplant like the ones at ali baba's cafe, and are smaller, but my bf said they have more meat.

The hot sauce wasn't as hot.
author: Skye W.

description:
Truly cheap - especially to split a deluxe falafel (and dude, those servings are MASSIVE, so you should probably split one, or at least make it a two-mealer)!  

We came in on a Sunday night and a few people popped in and out to get their wraps to go, so we had the mirrored counter space to ourselves.  The wrap was stuffed with eggplant, fried potatoes, falafel, a touch of spicy paste stuff, a smidge of spicy onions, loads of cuke cubes, and excellent sauce.  I'm gonna try one of the meats next time - I do so enjoy meat on a stick.

The mirrored wall was great for a final food-in-teeth inspection on our way out the door.
author: Laura B.

description:
3.5 stars. I think it's because I love the fat in lamb shawarma and it was really lean at this place. However, the flavors were still there.

I loved the bread it was in. Not quite like a tortilla, but it's actually a large rectangular flat bread. After they stuff the wrap, they grill it so it's chewy yet crispy when you eat it. I thought that was GENIUS.
author: Beverly T.

description:
7X7 Big Eat #97 Lamb Shawerma at Truly Mediterranean. MEH I think the main problem here was that the lamb was dry and the price was about $9 after tax. I was expecting juicy chunks of lamb, but I got dry bits that were cut up a little too fine so it tasted almost like... dirt. Fuuuu.

The lavash-burrito-style wrap didn't help much either to the wrap as it also added to the dryness overall. The people working there were nice and able to separate the wrap into two separate smaller wraps, but the price didn't really feel right for what we were eating.

Beginning to think this 7X7 Big Eat list is pretty unreliable goshhh.
author: Charles L.

description:
Now that I reviewed Sunrise deli, I am on a falafel reviewing kick and I have to say that in my humble middle-eastern food snob opinion, this is my next best choice for a falafel sandwich - only this time it is a wrap and they add eggplant (if you order the deluxe) which makes my mouth water.  The falafel itself is great (though second to Sunrise), but really the two places are hard to compare, given the tremendous style difference. This place is more like a walk-up stand. 

Out in the mission late one evening and hungry for something tasty? Stop by and get a memorable wrap, though more costly than a burrito.  There won't be any middle easterners in the store, but the system is down pat.  My personal preference is the falafel, but my second choice is the shawerma (lamb/beef).  It depends on my mood.  All the wraps are a good size and are very very filling.  Have at it my fellow falafel lovers!
author: N F.

description: I TRULY don't have anything to compare with TRULY Mediterranean cause this is the first place I've ever had a shawerma. But for being my first shawerma, it's TRULY pretty good. The combination of lamb and onions and some kinda sauce all put in a wrap. I think I'm Truly ready to travel to Turkey and have some kebobs, shawermas, and hummus. I think it's truly cool how the lamb is slowly cooked on the spin rod. I plan on coming again. Truly good.
author: Michael L.

description:
Do come if you enjoy being oogled by unseemly men from behind the counter.

Do come if you enjoy amazing falafels, just the right amount of crispy balls, fresh cut cucumbers,  crunchy sliced onions + extra spicy hot sauce.

And last but not least, do come if you enjoy discovering a tiny piece of hair in your food, mid-bite.
author: Lisa W.

description:
The first time I ate here, I was sick the next day.  This place was one of the two suspected culprit restaurants; however I am pleased to announce that multiple subsequent trips have mostly disproved this theory.

Falafel here is so yummy in my tummy, though I've also tried the chicken, which, though not as impressive, is up to par.  My favorite is the mediterranean plate, because the hummus here is just so tasty--this happens to be one of my favorite spots for hummus.

Affordable, and the staff is always friendly.  It's a bummer that you can't really sit down here, except for at the counter along the wall, which is really awkward because there's a mirror so you gotta have someone to talk to and look at purposefully without feeling awkward (if you get awkward about those sorts of things like I do).

I've gotta bump down a star though because one time there was a weird lid swap situation that made me feel like it could have been unsanitary... when they could have just thrown it out and assured me there was a clean new one...
author: Brianna H.

description:
My husband and I first went to Truly Mediterranean after we saw their profile on one of those "Eye on the Bay" shows.  We drove all the way from San Jose. This place was a delight. We met the owner- we told him how we saw his restaurant and had to make the HOUR+ drive to try his Shawerma. He even gave us desert for free. 

WOW RIGHT?!?  

Ok, now this past week I was in the city with my daughter and a friend. I could not wait to bring them to Truly Med. for my 'Rave Review Shawerma' The lady taking our order was polite. The owner and two other employees were their.  I asked the owner about the meat and what was in the full wrap. He went on to say the Shawermas meat mix of lamb and beef along with onions, etc..  I ordered 3 lamb/beef Shawermas. The owner himself made our order. Our order was to-go. Arriving at our picnic site we started to eat our lunch and to our surprise none of our SHAWERMAS had any meat?!?  And to add more insult to this order my daughter whom is 13 and my friend started to tell me as I was ordering the employees were looking at my daughter with nasty, pervert looks.  I will not be returning to this place.
author: Karen P.

description: Great shawerma. Great falafel. The menu is limited to a few great items. The food is made fresh and is very authentic. My favorite shawerma spot in San Francisco.
author: Ahmed H.

description:
Everyone loves this place, and I do too. Tiny, yet very tidy, clean space. I always get the falafel deluxe with hot sauce. I love that they toast the lavash on the grill after assembly --makes a huge difference. Their falafel is always crisp and delicious. The fried potatoes and eggplant are not greasy, and have a nice "smoky" flavor. Make sure to get extra feta if you want your tastebuds to sing. Mmmmmm.....

5 stars for the owner's deadpan humor. I love that guy!
author: Antoi C.

description: Delicious falafels that are green just like in Egypt :-) Not a ton of seating, but doesn't seem to hard to find a table. The vegetarian pkaye is $9.50 and a decent amount of food. Way better than other Mediterranean places (I.e. 19th and Valencia.
author: Robin L.

description:
The chicken schawerma changed my life (in a good way).  'nuff said.

As for their famed falafel deluxe...
I'm not a huge fan of Falafel (though, it is fun to say...falafel falafel falafel), but heard so much ranting and raving about this place, that I HAD to try it.  It was the best falafel I've ever had... but I still hate falafel (falafel falafel).  

I won't dock them stars for that though, it's just not my favorite food.  5*s for quick and polite service, clean (but tiny) facility, and AMAZING chicken schawerma .
author: Ron C.

description: I swear, if the shawarma goes up in price again (over $10.00), I'm never setting foot inside. I was there since the early days (2000-2001) when it was only $7 and now (2013) it jumped to $9.30, freaking hella steep!!!
author: Corey T.

description:
My boyfriend got the metal button on his rear pant pocket seriously stuck in gap between white plastic chair slats outside Truly Med on 16th and Valencia on a busy Saturday afternoon. I can only conclude that his lamb shawerma was so good, he did not want to leave. 

Best best falafel in the area: It is crisp on the outside, delightful on the inside, has excellent flavor and spice -  definitely not soaked in grease to make up for lack of taste like some other places around here. 

+ tahini sauce is awesome - not bitter, very flavorful. 
+ hot sauce is even better!!**
+ combo plate is generous and well-appointed! Unlike other joints where you have to pick 3 items only, you get some of everything here (dolma, falafel, pita, humous, baba ganoush, cucumber salad, huge feta chunks, tabuleh..). Get one and eat it in the park.
+ falafel wrap is killer. Lavash is grilled to perfection.

**If you ask for extra hot sauce for your giant wrap, they will give you a pokey stick object to ensure you get all that hot sauce into your wrap and evenly distributed. 

The atmosphere is not exactly scenic, but the guys at the counter are always smiling... even when your partner person is threatening to abscond with one of their cheap plastic chairs because it is stuck to his arse.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
mmmmmm.  This place was so good-  I cannot believe that I had not been here before until this evening, when my friend coerced me into going there.  YUM!  We were going to go to Luna Park, but I am glad we went there instead.

We both had the lamb shawarma and they wrapped it up with the spiciest sauce and feta cheese.



Very cool, and I will definitely go back for more one day.  Oh yeah, the people that worked there were nice, and I think they sell CD's too.
author: Lisa M.

description:
I will someday eat again at Truly Mediterranean... 

I had the lamb Shawerma (delicious) and 1 delicious falafel and I recommend it to anyone looking for a quick tasty bite in the area especially if they want to walk with their meal.
author: Alex W.

description: Ahhhhh Truly Mediterranean, I was so looking forward to your lamb shawerma but the first bite I took had a huge piece of hair in it. :( Now, I do not mind if Truly Mediterranean is a hole in the wall restaurant because most authentic restaurants are but so long as it keeps up with its health standards. Eeekk no thank you. Perhaps another day Truly Medierranean when your health standards are pulled up a notch.
author: Megan D.

description:
"Next, please? Next, please?" There's no one waiting! Yet the servers won't let up. So I decide to get the combo plate. Everything is bland. The baba ganoush, the hummus, the dolmas, the cheese. The pita bread tastes odd.

Friend gets the chicken kebab. Also bland. And a huge mess to eat. Dark soggy eggplant + old looking fry does not equal tasty-looking.

Too much good food around this area to try this place again.
author: Jen Y.

description: After watching the Avengers last week, I knew I had to grab some shawarma.  So, I went over here and grabbed their lamb shawarma, along with their garlic flavored yogurt.  The yogurt definitely packed a lot of garlic, and the shawarma itself was pretty good.  It came out rather quick with a good amount of people in line at night.  Sure it's a hole-in-the-wall, but it definitely serves its purpose
author: Ren L.

description: Just ate here again.... the shawerma is delicious, but you gotta ask for extra hot sauce if you really want it spicy.  It's full of flavor and the flatbread it's wrapped in gets grilled perfectly.  Next time I want to ask for potatoes and cucumbers inside though cause that's what i love about the falafel deluxe.
author: Julie B.

description: I don't like the shwarma and they're pricey.
author: Michael E.

description:
Reminds me of a great shawarma place in Belfast. 
Possibly the best mid-eastern wrap of my life.
Great to know I can come here now. :)
40c falafel? Of that quality and freshness? Crumbling deliciousness and popping sesame flavor all over your mouth?
mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm
Absolutely amazing how that heaping moundof  tahini perfectly combined with the filling ingredients after the bread was rolled and grilled....
mmmmmmmmmmmm, grilled.
author: Dario B.

description: My husband loves this place so I gave it a try. I got the Kefta Kebab wrap and it was just OK....not enough flavor in the actual meat. My husband got the Lamb Schwerma and that was delicious!  The wraps are huge. Also got a side order of falafels (4 pieces) and they were so moist and fresh.
author: Karrie F.

description:
Excellent Mediterranean! Chicken shawarma is awesome. Simple menu, decent prices, nice people! My girlfriend got the veggie platter and everything on it was to die for. I make my own hummus at home and wish mine could be as good as this was! She particularly likes things to be tahini friendly.

Be prepared this is a small restaurant with only a few seats, more of a take out place than a sit down affair.
author: Seth W.

description:
I've heard a lot about the schwarma. And so I was exited to try it.

I was disappointed. The meat was bland and the yogurt sauce was too. 

For the price, I wasn't impressed. And to be sure, I tried it again at a later date--still not so impressed.

Although I live nearby, I won't be eating here anymore.
author: Inga B.

description: Go here.  It is amaze balls.  I always get whatever meat is on the slow cooker with my shawarma and have them add two falafels + double the spicy sauce.  Don't go for the decor this is a food only experience.
author: Michael G.

description:
This wasn't the best Schwarma I have ever had. It was actually a little bland. My wife had the Athens Burger rolled up in a Lavash, and I think that was better than my meal. I don't travel to the mission often, but when I do I want to be excited about what I'm eating, and that just didn't happen this time.  

Sorry 7 x 7... you let me down on this one!
author: Miguel V.

description:
OMG...I think right after Thai, Mediterranean food is my new thang!!!

I don't eat much in there but the little I do eat is EXPLOSIVE :)

My friend was like Sandra let's go have dinner.  I'm like...SURE...I'm always up to stuffing my mouth and gut :)
She was like ok there's this mediterranean place that's super good but its a hole in the wall.  I'm like ARE YOU KIDDING ME...I'm a hole in the wall kinda girl.  I love hole in the walls.  They are the best!!!!

So we walk in and yes just my kinda place.  But I like at the guys behind the counter, I look at my friend, I look at the menu, then back at my friend.  Here's how it went:

HER: What's wrong
ME:  I thought you said this was mediterranean

HER:  It is
ME:  (whisphering...so I thought) then why are they Latin
HER:  (cracking up) so...they how to cook mediterranean
Dude behind counter:  Yea...no problem (latin accent) we can cook

ME: Hmmm I don't know girl
HER: Girl please...let me get a chicken schwerma
ME:  Ohhh kay now...I'll have a...(can't remember the name)
Dube behind the counter:  I'll make yours extra special
ME:  GREAT (feeling the disappointment already lol)

Food comes out and I'm like OMG!!!!!!!!!!!!  This sh@t is GREAT!!!!!!!!!
The falafeel balls were done to perfection.  The tahini sauce complimenting it just right.  The hummus, a bit on the cold side but jeeze...I felt like I died and went to Persia :)  The baba ganush (excuse the bad spelling) was EXTRAVAGANT!  

ME:  Happy as hell, 
HER:  SEEE I TOLD YOU
Dude behind the counter:  You like or you love
ME:  I LOVE :)
HER: Laughing her heart out
Dude behind the counter:  Play some music (as the music starts blasting in the hole in the wall)
ME: Dancing in front of my stool, stuffing my face w/falafeels and tahini sauce and having the time of my life!!!!

Nothing more to say!!!!!!!!!!
As we head out we say our thank yous.  I say great job boys and dude behind the counter says you come back tomorrow and I scream HELL YEA and he says...I'm not here tomorrow come Friday.  And I was like For sheezie!!!!!
author: Sandra S.

description: Another local joint that serves up great shawerma. just keep in mind that they only serve chicken on tuesdays and fridays. service was quick and food was delicious. very skeptical to try the chicken at first.
author: John N.

description:
This place is up and down for me.  I think they have great lamb, falafel, chicken, and eggplant, but their tabouli and cucumber salads have got to be the worst in the city.  Their veggie plates are pretty decent -- taste and price.  I like their baba and roasted tomatoes.  They have good babs and hummus.

One of the best things about this place is their yogurt garlic mint drinks!  You have to try this.  They are made from plain yogurt, garlic, and mint -- no sugar.

Other info:

Great customer service.

Parking can be hard.

They accept credit cards.

You can buy any amount of eggplant you want -- $2.00's worth, etc.

Not much seating.  They have some inside (no tables; only a counter) and a couple of tables outside.  

It can get cold in there if you eat there.
author: Dicky V.

description: Very delicious! The staff was friendly and there was no wait. It was my first time coming here, so it took half a minute to decide what to order. The falafel was great, not over cooked or under seasoned. I feel like it was right on point. The baklava was very good, exactly what I expected. I would definitely say that it was what I expected, which is just normal mediterranean food. It most certainly didn't exceed my expectations. I was very pleased though! I would definitely come back.
author: Alexia M.

description: Conveniently located a couple doors down from the Roxie, this place has one of the best falafel wraps I've ever tasted. I was skeptical at first while volunteering at the theater for a film festival, but I kept seeing (and SMELLING) the wraps that the people were eating while waiting in line for the films to start.  I couldn't take it anymore...the silly wraps were taunting me, so I got my wallet and ordered the falafel deluxe. No wonder the yelp rating is so high...the toasted wrap with crispy falafels was enhanced by the eggplant flavor.  SUPER YUM!
author: Wing Man C.

description: It's hard to find a good shawerma in the city. After being super disappointed from one place, I was lazy and didn't know where else to go. But on a random walk, stopped here, and was pretty satisfied. Great chicken shawerma. Loved the sauce in it and how it just oozed out. And I love how it didn't break apart in my hands and didn't taste super dry like Ali Baba's Cave in Lower Haight. Major plus.
author: April D.

description:
I have loved this spot for years and was reminded just how much yesterday. Fantastic chicken shawarma! Best I've ever had! And, of course, the falafel is never a bad choice. 

The one issue I had and the only one I think I have ever had here is the tabouli salad. Sadly that was the worst I think I've ever had. I was $4.25 for a half pint of chopped curly leaf parsley....VERY little to no tomato, bulgar, cucumbers, green onions, herb, sauce, etc....  I mean really!? $4.25 for chopped cheap parsley? Not even Flat-leaf parsley. I was kinda pissed by it actually, but not enough to downgrade my review. One bad item/experience is not enough for me to forsake a great history of good food.
author: A J.

description:
These guys are very friendly, and conveniently located. But they have a problem. Their tahini sauce tastes terrible. It is bitter and often grainy. 

It's definitely worth the walk down to 19th for a superior falafel experience at Ali Baba's.
author: jeff g.

description: Most amazing shawarma  and falafel I have had in this country. Coming from and Arab that means alot! Super nice owner.
author: arwa m.

description:
I've had my fair share of Mediterranean food in SF. This place is NOT 4 STAR quality...it's more like when you take a bite of something and your like, "meh. I've had better...then it gets worse as you eat it because you think about how good this could be...and how you paid $8 for something you could have paid $6." 

I think all the drunk people who come from all the bars come here to eat and are too fucked up to notice a difference. If you want some good Mediterranean falafel, shawarma ( gyro) check out Yumma's in the inner sunset...you will notice a BIG difference.
author: Nick C.

description: Best hole in the wall Mediterranean spot in the city.  Lamb shawarma is lean and delightfully spiced.
author: Alex B.

description: Yum! I had my personal favorite shawarma place in mind when trying Truly, so everything was held in comparison to that. First of all the prices were a bit more expensive, but that is to be expected because it is in San Francisco and is popular. Second of all, the quality of food was pretty good. The lamb is shredded pretty finely, their hot sauce burns pleasantly, and the wrap itself is thrown on the grill for a nice crisp exterior. I thoroughly enjoyed the wrap, but it still doesn't top my favorite. We were left wishing for some more yogurt sauce to balance out the saltiness of the lamb and the spiciness of the hot sauce.
author: Sannie L.

description: it's a hole in the wall place with decent lamb shwarma for $9ish. There's better out there but if you just wanna eat without fuss and fast, do it. There are only about 5 bar seats. otherwise, you could find a better place if you looked. Def had better in LA.
author: Emm C.

description:
Lamb was dry. My friend and I are planning to come back when it's busier.

When we arrived, we were the only customers there and in 10 minutes there was a line. I am sure those customers got nice and juicy lamb.

If you do notice that the lamb they are putting on your shawarma, I recommend quickly telling them you want it hot off the grill
author: Eric A.

description:
I had no idea what the heck I was in for, but the lamb shawerma is on the Big Eats SF list so I plopped down my $8, waited a few minutes and VIOLA, I was handed what appeared to be a Mediterranean burrito. More specifically, a BABY SHEEP burrito.

It was good but not OMG I NEED TO EAT MORE BABY SHEEP BURRITOS good and it wasn't until I was about halfway through it that it really started to grow on me. Now it's the next day and I'm stitting here thinking about how delicious another baby sheep burrito would be.

Friendly service and delicious baby sheep burritos.

Baa.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Oh my what a brilliant find!  While strolling through the Valencia area, my friend and I found "Truly". And truly it is!  Fresh, full of flavor and traditional.  Friendly people working there as well, which is always welcome.  The only thing I regret is not getting an extra plate for leftovers :)). Mmm. Mmmm Mmm!!!!
author: Alisa F.

description: Da muh fuh BOMB.com....the only complaint I have is that there should be no chicken...lamb only please. Ask for extra hot sauce!
author: Leon H.

description: This is a shawarma place located in the Mission District of San Francisco.  When I went here I tried the lamb shawarma, which was very good and flavorful.  You can have them put fries in it if you like (steak fries) and then they put it in a wrap and grill the wrap so it's all nice and hot.  A definite must-visit if you're in the area and are in the mood for shawarma or other Middle Eastern food.
author: Sushi X.

description:
I spotted this place one night and decided to go somehere else. Worst mistake ever! I had been dreaming about going back ever since and yesterday I finally did. Honestly, after getting the Falafel Delux, I'm STILL FULL! It was so so so good. And at $8 with tax for this bigger than a Mission burrito flatbread sammy, a great break on the wallet too. 

I can't wait to go back and will recommend it to everyone I meet.
author: Greg G.

description:
3.5 stars actually...very close to 4 stars, if it weren't for the slightly dry lamb meat...otherwise, quite tasty! Service was friendly and efficient. Lots of meat, sauce, onions..nicely hot and toasty!

I'd come back here and try the chicken schawarma for sure...I'd like to give this place 4 stars.
author: Carol L.

description: By far the best falafel wraps that I've ever had. It's the roasted eggplants that seals the deal. I have no idea how they roast/bake those little suckers to be so moist and flavorful, but its addition makes the wraps heavenly. The falafel balls are very fresh too. I've had a few bites of the lamb and chicken shwarmas and they were excellent too.
author: Alice W.

description:
Alright, I gotta write this review before AI blows a gasket. What to say..what to say..

Ambiance: None. It's a total hole in the wall. It's the mission. Are you surprised? 
Service: Quick. They know what they are and they know what they're not. And the faster they get you to the food the better.
Food: Ahh...the food. I went with a bona fide shawarma expert so my expectations were high going into it. This place did not disappoint. In that, I'm still thinking about the damn lamb shawarma I had last night and what I'm going to try the next time I go in.

I know there are tons of places to check out in the mission, so I'm going to be perfectly honest with you...if you go on a Thursday or Saturday (or not through), first check out Mission Street Food (sorry Anand). Any other day, go to Truly Med.

To come in second in the mission is saying something and this place definitely deserves recognition. Anyway, stop reading this and get your ass over there.
author: Shreya C.

description:
It was a-ok thats for sure. I didn't like the service, frankly the personality was of a wet mop but who knows maybe he was having a bad day. 

I had a chicken shawarma and the chicken was very dry, had the ends and bits of whatever was left is what it tasted like. All I could say was I've had better. I should know because I am middle eastern and have been eating this food all my life. 

I also hate it when they charge you for every little thing too. Sorry not a fan.
author: Sourma K.

description: Oh how I miss the old days. Unfortunately my 21 year affair with this place has come to an end because of $6. I won't be going back because of short sided business views over a Groupon. I went in today with a Groupon that expired yesterday but of course the face value is still usable at $12. However, it was refused even when I showed in black and white that the voucher NEVER EXPIRES. I explained this and was told "I understand" but clearly this is not the case. I was ready to spend the usual $25-30 less the 12 but this meant nothing. It actually behooves a business when a Groupon expires. So the fact that I was willing to spend more, had been going here for 21 years and the Groupon still had value didn't matter and I was simply told "I'm sorry." But I'm actually sorry that the value of $6 was more than the hundreds and hundreds I would spend if you stayed open another 21 years. There was no financial loss to you today but you couldn't see that. For that I am sorry for you because I have to think there will be more like me with Groupons and what will you do when other things in business pop up? Always take the short view? This will not keep you in business long. Two stars because I love the food. The food which I will never have again. Another lesson for me in MY business and what not to do. I hope you read this and ACTUALLY understand the losses. I think the old owners understood this.
author: Misti L.

description: I had the deluxe falafel wrap. It was very large, quite cheap, and very delicious! The place is kind of a hole in the wall, so don't expect any ambiance. It's also a little annoying that if you just want tap water, you have to go up to the counter and have them to refill it. There's no big vat or water dispenser like other restaurants.
author: Marko J.

description:
Last night, a friend asked me, "You just lovvve being carniverous, dontcha Steph?" Well, I do, and my favorite of all meats is lamb.

But who can really afford to eat lamb on the regular? Me!

My roommate and I gorge ourselves on shwarma weekly. I go big and order the lamb shwarma and add hummus and cucumber salad to it. It's squishy and enormous and oh, just delicious. Sometimes I'll even just pop in for a side of hummus and pita - cheap, quick yumminess.

An added bonus is that the guys behind the counter always put a smile on my face... and that ain't just the lamb talkin.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
This is hands down my favorite mediterranean place. 

I brought a friend who is apparently pretty picky when it  comes to mediterranean, and after I heard him say "this is sooo goood" like 20 times, I knew I had done right. I always enjoy this place if I need a quick eat in the mission. 

Their falafels are sooooo boooomb. Yep, I said "bomb." (How early 90's am I???) Crispy on the outside, nice and moist on the inside. And their chicken shawarma is always so juicy and flavored perfectly! 

The only thing this place lacks is seating, because I know people would love to just kick it here and eat....but at the same time, I guess waiting in line for your food and salivating while you watch them make it, then making other people drool and stare at you as if you're the hot meat on a stick because you're looking like you're so enjoying that food is what makes this hole-in-the-wall place a commodity.
author: Emy s.

description: I went for the lamb shwerma and was not disappointed! I got it with hot sauce, which added more flavor, and the lamb was well-cooked and not dry. I didn't really like that the lamb was near the door and not behind any barrier. The baklava I got was also really good, so I'll most likely be going back.
author: Sydney K.

description: The only place I've had better Shawerma is in Berlin.
author: William W.

description:
I always like trying new things, so I was intrigued by their garlic-yogurt drink. 

But it's a simple tzatziki sauce. Which is meant to be spooned onto gyros and other yummy Mediterranean dishes, not drank. And when it is drank, i'ts unpleasant. Their food isn't terrible, I'm just mad that they try to make money off of sellign a sauce as a drink.

But even so, Ali Baba's Cave, despite being more than twice the size of this place (higher rent), manages to give you a bigger, and more delicious falafel wrap for less.
author: Mark A.

description:
Fantastic value, where else in the city can you get a great meal & soda for $10?   

On the downside, parking SUCKS, tables are essentially non-existent and they don't sell lamb wraps on Tues. & Fridays, they sell chicken instead and if you ask me, it doesn't cook well on the spit, it's always dry.
author: Bill O.

description:
This place makes falafels right. WOO!

I really wanted to try the lamb schwarma, but I went on Friday and the only two days that they don't have lamb schwarma is Tuesday and Friday. On those two days they have chicken schwarma instead. 

Disappointed to find that there was no lamb schwarma today, I ordered the falafel deluxe, which just come with eggplant and onions included with the falafel wrap option which is another menu item. The staff is extremely nice and make the wraps large (My guy friends that came with me were all stuffed afterwards..and these guys eat a lot, too). 

The restaurant itself is rather small and can seat around 4-5 people along the opposite side of the wall from where they cook. Food served on one side, food eaten on the other. There are a couple tables outside, but it's cold in SF. I've never been to this area before, so luckily I did have some guy friends with me. This part of the Mission is a little creepy at night (to me at least). 

But anywho, this hole-in-the-wall joint is a Mediterranean gem in the Mission. Definitely grab some food here and be prepared to stay satisfied and full for a while.
author: Julia K.

description:
Delicious falafel wrap! 
Quick service if the line isn't too long.
Cheap n easy!

Can be eaten while walking to your favorite bar in Mission or Castro. Ask for no onions cause no one wants to talk to a dude with onion breath, no matter how hot he is! Be careful as to not drip sauce on your skinny jeans or your buffalo plaid flannel.
author: Rex D.

description:
so my friend's been hyping this place up for a long time and im like a bit skeptical then last week were all hanging out at dolores park and we got hungry...haha so we walked to this place and i got a lamb schwarma (i dont even know if thats the correct spelling but im too lazy to google it right now cause its cold as fuck and im all curled up in my own blanket) with 2 falafels in it...man the sec i took a bite out of it......i felt like the angels were hailing from the sky with trumpets, drums and shit and their hot sauce.........IS THE SHIzNIT! i fuckin love their hot sauce, i had my SCHWARMA extra hot sauce and i had some more of it, def. recommend this place

4 stars
author: Michael K.

description:
Truly Awful,
Okay. I had stopped going here awhile back.  I got into the convenience, and their filling, and somewhat tasty falafels Then certain things would happen. They would have strange portions, prices shot up, rudeness, they began to be out of things such as lamb, etc... and I started to get the "this is just a fast food place, in disguise vibe.  Granted, I will be honest, the food here is tasty. That's why they get the two stars rather than the unfair one star... 
Well, I went back the other day. They were out of the lamb again. It was so frustrating. I think I will wait another couple of years to go back. 

PS. The falafel place down the street, on Valencia is much better. Better vibe, better service, and just as good falafel if not better. 

PPS Some great falafel .. is... in West Oakland, on Telegraph near 30th, www.oasisfoodmarket.com Its new. Service is slower, but the food is great.I cannot imagine them ever being out of anything since they also run a meat counter, and grocery store.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Solid Mediterranean food. The first time I went, I ordered the "Falafel Deluxe," which is a "Falafel Regular" but with eggplant and potatoes. I don't really like eggplant and I find potatoes in my wrap to be out of place, but I'm a sucker for anything labeled "Deluxe" or "Supreme" or the like (in other words, I'm American).

I got the Falafel Regular on my second trip, which I liked better. Good falafel, nice diced cucumber mix, and tasty tzaziki sauce. Next time I need to try the garlic mint yoghurt drink.
author: Adam B.

description: Had the lamb shawarma wrap,  excellent!!!!!  Small place with limited seating,  the wrap was very, very good. The people working there are very helpful with the menu as well.
author: Peter G.

description:
Came here last night and ordered a falafel deluxe.  After ordering, I found out what makes it deluxe - they add potatoes and eggplant.  Turns out, that shit is delicious.  To me, the potato in the falafel was kind of like rice in a burrito; it has to be really flavorful on its own or it doesn't add anything but filler to the falafel.  But the eggplant was well-prepared, sweet and tangy and eggplanty.  I'd never had either ingredient in a falafel before, but now that I've seen the light I'm hooked.

I think the falafel could have used more tahini sauce, but this was the best falafel I've had in the city.  I also got a few dolmas, which were pretty good.  Not as good as Myconos, but good nonetheless.

Definitely a good, healthier alternative to burritos if you've had too many of those (and not because you're tired of them, because burritos are way too awesome for that to happen, but sometimes you need to take a break for health reasons).  

I'm eager to try their other stuff, I'm thinking next visit I'll get a shawerma.
author: Joseph N.

description: 3.5..Tried the lamb shawerma.Loved the way it was spiced.The lamb was a bit dry and the tomatoes tasted off.It was made as a wrap and I should have ordered it on pita.The lamb kebab was probably the better way to go. The people working there are very nice.The sandwich is huge and a good value at 9 bucks. Get it to go..
author: Bleep S.

description:
I'd rather eat the falafel wrap at Ali Baba's Cave. (ABC)

I don't like how the bread here is so thick and there is less filling.  I also think the falafel is crispier and crunchier at ABC.  The falafel here for me, is a whole lot of meh

Plus I hate how the place is set up.  When there are more than 5 people in there, it feels like you can't move without always bumping into people.  Yeah it's small, but the layout sucks ass.
author: Jung L.

description:
My review is based strictly on take-out service:

I never seem to call on the lamb shwarma days but the food here is always consistent in above-par quality but the cost is a bit steep.
author: Selina L.

description: Best Mediterranean food in this hole in the wall place in mission! Must try falafel, hummus and wraps. Extremely cheap, but let that not throw you away.
author: Karthik N.

description:
I love their chicken Shawarma, their lamb/beef Shawarma. In fact, all their Shawarmas are yuuummmmmy.

Compared to Shawarmas from other places, which are usually soaked in grease hence hard to hold and taste badly, Truly's Shawarma is just right in moisture. The outside is also crispy. 

If you want something great and quick. This is it. Don't expect fancy seating etc from a real restaurant.
author: Lo Y.

description:
Here's your contrarian review - I've been visiting Truly Mediterranean for over a year now and in my opinion their quality has steadily deteriorated. I tried the Chicken Shawerma for the first time today and my entire experience was a wash. The gentleman serving the wraps had a gruff demeanor and he was miserly with the sauce. 

The chicken itself was drier than paper and my lunch was pretty much ruined. Not recommended.
author: ubaid d.

description:
I was a little hasty in giving it a 5 star review before.

Yes, the falafel is superb. Lamb and chicken are completely below average. The service is fast, but the workers are the biggest piece of shits I've ever met. They talk openly about bangin' broads and insulted me, because I didn't hear that my order was up. 

Oasis grill is wayyyyyy better and I'm not some SF douche with an eclectic taste. I'm from NYC where Mediterranean food is at its best. Mamoun's anyone?
author: Yelena E.

description:
Truly Mediterranean = Truly Unspectacular

Entering, my stomach growled in delight, as the lamb shawerma boldly presents itself in the doorway, slowly roasting, dripping its succulent juices on itself. I planned on a chicken kebab wrap but after a minute engulfed in the scent of lamb, my mind was made up - an order of shawerma could not be passed up.

When the counter-help taking my order, does a 180 for the grill and grabs what looks like a metal cake pan full of cut shawerma and tomatoes and forks over a heap into my to-go dinner container, I wonder about the juicy spit I was drooling over.

At first bite, I had to wonder, was the lamb spit I was sold on for show not for go? A tease. Blasphemy! Not expecting smoking hot as the food was a to-go order, the meat was barely luke warm and had quite a bit of chew to it. Seems as though this pan atop the grill was merely a vessel rather than a means for keeps the meat hot, juicy, and delicious. Re-heating the meat at this point yielded only a slight improvement but was mostly a lost cause. The lamb's accompaniments added bulk (and the glorious onion breath we all desire) to the meal but not much else.

To scoop up smooth, but not overly creamy, and yes, quite flavorful hummus, we received oodles of heated pitas. Quantity does not make up for quality though and while the hummus hit the spot, the rest of the meal left me longing. If I were to go back, I'm just going to sink my teeth into the spit and tear off a chunk of that which I drooled over initially. Such a disappointment.
author: Alissa A.

description:
I don't know what all the hype about this place is about.  It is not the greatest Mediterranean place in SF but not the worse either.  I had the shawerma which came out smoking hot wrapped in a crispy wrap.  

Maybe I was just expecting too much but the shawerma was just average.
author: Danny P.

description:
Love this place! I take the BART from Berkeley to 16th st just to eat there when I'm in town!

It's VERY small, but all good. My only issue is they don't serve beef everyday. Only Monday / Wednesday / Friday. Other  days it's chicken. 

Because the place is so small, they only have room for 1 skewer rack. 

But I still love it!
author: Shad A.

description:
Yesterday we were having a dozen and half people over to warm our new place. We wanted to make things really easy on ourselves, so we went to Truly Mediterranean and ordered a combo platter. For $75, it's not only a significant amount of food for 20 people, but it's delicious taste is impressive.

Hummus, baba ghanoush, tabbouleh, cucumber salad, many cubes of feta, dozens of dolma, and a large bag of falafel. A container for the yogurt dressing and one for the spicy sauce. Unfortunately, no onions. Maybe that's not appropriate party food? You also get plentiful pita.

The reception the beautiful platter of food got was fantastic. Everyone loved it. Everyone asked where we got it. In the future, Truly Med should menus with their platters. I'm sure they'd get even more business if they were to.

I recommend ordering in advance. We didn't, but I could tell that it would've been helpful to them if we had.

So if you're looking for value and a feast for your fiesta, try Truly Med. Vegetarians will be appreciative. And, I'm sure everyone else will as well.
author: Dave B.

description: I ordered the lamb shawerma as others had commented.  To my surprise instead of cutting the meat from the rotating hunk of meat they went into a pre cut metal container.  Who knows when this was actually cut.  Based on the taste it could have been from the previous day.  I found the food old, dry, and tasteless.  No thank you.  oh, the place is also very dirty.
author: Orry M.

description: Solid little falafel/shawarma shop. Nothing much to it...just about four stools, a counter and a lot of meat. Go for either the lamb shawarma wrap or the falafel wrap. Both are pretty solid choices and damn cheap. Gotta love getting extra hot sauce!
author: Scott T.

description:
Mediterranean food was the one flavor I though SF to be lacking. This place, however, was "truly" a great find.  Phenomenal Falafel and Lamb Schwarma.  Hard to imagine anything better than their Falafel Wrap.

And why is their falafel so darn good? First, all the ingredients were very fresh.  The falafel also had the perfect texture and taste. They use seasoned cucumbers and onions, which add to the texture contrast.  Their Tahini sauce is perfect, and the special hot sauce on the inside of the wrap brings so much flavor to the falafel wrap.  Lastly , the wrap itself is toasted and lightly crunchy. Just the way I like it.

Not expensive, but priced just above the normal hole-in-the-wall restaurants.  For a small hole-in-the-wall place, these folks run a tight kitchen.  Everything was very clean, and well organized.  You can tell these guys have the Mediterranean mojo.
author: Gregory C.

description:
Hunting around for parking in the Mission was rewarded with a delicious lamb shawarma.  I love my mediterranean food, and this is definitely a place I'd go to again!

Thin slices of succulent lamb and beef were wrapped up with marinated onions, fresh herbs, a smear of hot sauce and a generous drizzle of tahini sauce.  After it was rolled together tightly, the shawarma was thrown on the grill for a minute to get the lavash warmed through and toasty.  Oh, it was SO good.  For about $8, it was enough to feed me for lunch and dinner.
author: Janet L.

description: Best grubby grub grub for a stomach full of gin and tonics on a Friday night.  My friend introduced me to this spot.  She raves about their falafel, cause she's a vegetarian.  However, I wanted meat, meat, meat!  I am a huge fan of lamb, but Friday is "no lamb day".  Bah!  Fine, chicken it is.  Taken off skewers after being grilled and slapped with some sauce, veggies and then wrapped with love.  "Warmed up", he asked.  "Yes please", and he lays it on the grill.   When you take a bite, you get a little bit of a toasted crunch on the wrap and then, and then. . . .paradise.  Haha, it was delicious.  Couldn't finish the darn thing either, but another hole in the wall gem in the Mission.  They have some desserts on display, limited beverages, but still, who cares.  Come here for the food.  It makes my mouth water just writing about it.
author: Janice F.

description: We went here on a recommendation from a New Yorker about how much better this place was compared to the falafels in New York and were very much disappointed. The food was fresh but quite bland and although the portions were large it wasn't worth the $41 we paid for four falafels. We were expecting more.
author: Angela T.

description: Decent hole in the wall Falafel Deluxe but the combination of being a little too spicy and lacking strong flavor is never ideal. 9$ is not exactly a steal when compared to comparable burritos in the area but solid for a quick grab if you don't feel like waiting in line.
author: Ojus P.

description: The shawerma's here are delicious. Get the falafel deluxe or the lamb deluxe and you're in for a big balanced treat. These days I always go for the falafel deluxe which includes 2 smushed up big fresh falafel pieces, few strips of soft grilled eggplant, seasoned diced potatoes, and their special garlic and hot sauce spread all rolled up in a wrap. After a few minutes of it being toasted nicely on their grill, it's ready to consume and enjoy. Havn't came across a shewerma place better than this in the city.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Every thing Ive ever eaten here has been tasty.

My fave, however is the chicken shawerma. Bring your appetite and love for slightly spicy and amazing Mediterranean food.
The chicken shawerma is only served on Tues and Friday though, but dont be afraid of the chicken kabob wrap or the falafel deluxe. They are both on par with aforementioned chicken shawerma.

Do NOT plan on sitting though. There are almost no seats and very limited space.
author: Jbot S.

description: according to all the other yelpers the lamb schwarma was the way to go, I was excited and made the trek to the mission.  Actually it was fairly good, but NOT for $8 (plus tax).  If it had been even $6, I would go up to 4 stars, but $8 and no real place to even eat it, except the grubby outside tables, or the weird skinny counter.  If you SF'ers want the best falafel of your lives, make the trek to San Jose for Falafel Drive in for a falafel and a banana shake combo. Now THAT is pure heaven.
author: Amy W.

description:
Great little place!
Love the Lamb Shawerma, lots of flavors combined!
We will soon come back !
author: Veronica M.

description:
More like a 2.5 star: I've been to this place twice and ordered the same thing - Deluxe Falafel. Unfortunately, I have to agree with John B.; although I ordered it spicy, it was actually quite bland, with the "deluxe" potatoes, eggplant and sauteed onions not adding any extra flavor. I ordered it to go, and when eating it at home, had my bottle of Tapatio at the ready for a generous, and frequent, dousing to help kick it up. The service is quick and friendly, the ingredients are fresh, it's huge and filling, and I like the grilled wrap, but I am a little disappointed with the flavor. However, I will give them another chance - they offer a vegetarian plate with babaganoush, falafel and other goodies, which might be better. But if the the babaganoush doesn't pass muster, I'm going to have to take my middle eastern/falafel business elsewhere. Life is too short!
P.S. a tiny space, but there is some limited seating - 5 stools against a shared counter, and sometimes seating outside.
author: Barbara K.

description:
I literally drive 2 hours to satisfy a lamb shawerma craving from truly med. the spicy red sauce is as epic as the red spice is mysterious?

Haven't found one a tenth as good anywhere within 45 minutes of Sacramento, and not for lack of effort . Soggy-assed tahini and lettuce filled "wraps" is what we keep getting.  Limp dissapointments incapable of producing anticipation or cravings.

I actually bring a huge sheet of heavy duty foil, go to truly med to stare longingly at my "lamb burro" being grilled (insert soft harp music here), wrap it tight in the foil, mad dash to post up at the marin headlands overlooking a foggy GG.... and rehash the "...take me now" feelings that magically combine with the harmony of culinary artistry and  ambience.

*** edit 12/11/09...  the mystical red spice that dusts the grilled onions and tomatoes has been positively IDd (with noted fervor by the Truly Med crew I might add... thanks for the tip, appreciated!)  as "sumac" 

Courtesy SpiceDepot.com  - "The sumac dried berry is not the poison sumac tree leaf, of course, but instead is a berry on a shrub that has grown wild in the Middle East since Neolithic times. It's sold as a reddish dried fruit that found in many Middle Eastern and Greek groceries in the form of a brick."

**** Chicken Shawerma: first blood II

Pulled the rare "back-to-backer" with madre y padre in town, Thursday featured the usual suspect... an ode to spicy lamb shawerma bliss (1st time asking for it "extra spicy" which produced a tongue salivating pleasure-to-pain ratio of about 4-1, perfect) that delighted all but the Stagecoach inn maid. Friday was the dreaded day of reckoning... 

Much like an understood mistress, I'd always known that there was this "other" shawerma,  yet I had always found myself inescapably blinded to variety by my craving for their grilledlamb. I had hoped  against hope that these poultry "infidels" were merely an option on tuesdays and fridays.... negative ghostrider. 

It's pollo time.... shiznit.... woe is me.... 
But wait, it has a "garlic yogurt" sauce replacing the tahini.... very interesting... hope springs eternal.

Verdict: while a breezy, almost sultry afternoon on Treasure Island sprung for extremely complimentary ambiance, the chicken shawerma failed to live up to the limited hype I had bestowed upon it. Even with the always appreciated extra red sauce, the lack of flavor depth in the chicken (through no fault of Truly Med) even as enhanced with garlic, could not hold a candle to its Baa Baa Black Sheep compatriot. 

lesson learned: while variety is indeed the spice of life, habitual use of sumac applied to a lamb burrito from the gods can make everyday remarkable.
author: Roadtrip B.

description:
Best.  Falafel.  Ever.  

HONGRY after a hard spinning workout and desperate for something non Mexican but still close to my house, Yelp led me here!

LIKES:
1. Falafel here is phenomenal!!
2. I ordered the Mediterranean Combo plate - good variety, and everything else tasted great: dolma, tabouleh, cucumber salad, feta, baba ganoush, hummus, and pita (in addition to the falafel).
3. Hearty serving size, and good value for the price!
4. Friendly service!  
5. Accepts credit cards! - Also a rare find in the Mission.

GRIPES:
1. It really is a hole in the wall, so there's not a ton of room to sit down and eat.  It's more of a take out place, but that being said, I got my food to go, and the falafel was still crispy on the outside, just the way I like it, 35 minutes later!

Blink and you'll miss it, but worth keeping your eyes (and your stomach) open for this delicious food!
author: Alice C.

description:
When I go to a taqueria I don't expect my food to be made by Greek guys so when I walked into Truly Mediterranean I considered it a bad sign that all the guys working there were Latin, does that make me a bigot?

The place is a run down little whole in the wall. That in itself isn't enough to subtract stars but since the food is bland and uncreative it doesn't help. Also he prices are too much for what you get.
author: Manny F.

description:
This tiny find in the mission is a real gem the best lamb shawarma wraps I have had on this coast. Super great prices simple menu and a real value i
My girl friend who is of Syrian descent says it the "best bubaganouch I have ever had" I am stingy with my 5s but this is a close to
author: William S.

description:
The first time I came here I was picking up two dozen falafel for a party, because my mom told me that Sunrise Deli in the sunset changed owners and now they use bad oil. 

When I first bit into the crunchy goodness that was the falafel, I knew my mom was right. It tasted fresh and oh my god so crunchy!!

The next time I went was with my now ex. I got the falafel wrap, and he got the lamb shewarma. Let me tell you, I was expecting more god-like crunchy falafel, but was a little disappointed. It was good, but not like how I remembered it. Then I tasted the lamb shewarma. I STILL DREAM ABOUT IT! Sometimes I feel like a pregnant woman cause I crave it so much. The juicy deliciousness of the meat, the crunchiness(i love crunchy things :P ) of the lavash, it's enough to make your mouth water, which mine definitely does. 

I really do need to go back, it's been too long. Plus, the girl who rings us up is always really nice. I like her :)
author: Liz F.

description:
Two words: Chicken Shwarma -- only available on Tuesday and Friday. 

I order it without onions and and ask for extra hot sauce. Don't forget to add a fresh squeezed carrot juice chaser.

Tip: Early afternoons are the best time to go. If it's crowded, you'll feel cramped and you won't enjoy it.

I'm a regular and I've been going here for years. The owner has a good memory and always remembers what I like, before I open my mouth.

Is it the absolute best? Most likely not, but you'll walk away satisfied. Sometimes I've eaten here twice in one day. It's really that good.
author: thrasher b.

description: The Valencia corridor has become the Mission's bohemian central with many dive bars and restaurants alone 16th . Night owls hit this spot before venturing to SOMA or the TL for night life .
author: Diego D.

description: Pretty good schwarma.  Zaytoon, which is a short walk, away is probably better, however, this place is faster.
author: Mike I.

description: I went today and got the regular falafel.  It was delicious.  I love this place.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Had the lamb shawarma and it was great! Very tasty with the right amount of spice and definitely was not greasy and some middle eastern food could be. The cucumber yogurt sauce was a great addition. The place is pretty small but it has a few bar stools to sit down. It's clean and the staff are friendly.
author: Azi Z.

description:
Pretty quick and great food.  Went there because of the 7x7 list but will definitely be back again.  Kind of a pain because you have to know that they don't have the lamb on Tuesday and Friday, but once you get that down this place is great.

Also, their falafel is really good.  I don't know about the best in the bay area as their plaques indicate, but definitely up there.
author: Jessica J.

description:
My favorite falafel in the city. 
Falafel Regular is the best thing they have. So delicious.
Shawarma, both Lamb and Chicken, are not that great .

5 stars for their Falafel Regular!!
author: Wakaknee J.

description: It was so so food was more than eatable, but not something to rave about, very little but on a busy street a lot to see would go back if in neighborhood
author: Keno M.

description:
i listened to a few fellow yelpers, i asked for extra sauce. and i shared. the gyro was tooooo big for just one person! and without the extra sauce, i can totally c that it would have been too dry for me. aside from that. i kinda wish it wasnt so much like a burrito but more with the real gyro wrap.... 


either way, i LOVED it. =) and i willl b back!
author: Lisa N.

description:
When I am aching for a giant, hot, wrap stuffed with the good lovin, I come here. I always get the Falafel Deluxe with Baba Ganoush instead of fries. 

Lavash, 'Spicy Paste' (optional..but..I don't understand why you wouldn't get it..), Tahinni Sauce, Baba Ganoush, cucumber, onions, and 5 fat Falafel Balls. This monster wrap is then tossed on the grill. Once you get your greedy paws on it..it's hot..crisped..and....

I can't even continue. I need to go there right now...
author: Natalie G.

description:
Big Eat SF list 2009 #89. Lamb schawerma

too gamey. or something. i'm not sure what. very very very lamby - not something i'm used to. but very huge - can easily make two meals..... i'm sure their other stuff is good...
author: S V.

description: The place is suuuper small, and the sitting area isn't that comfortable, so I wouldn't recommend eating here. That said, I used to live on 15th and Dolores and this place was clutch for an awesome take-out dinner. I can't comment on too many items on the menu, but the Shawarma (they have either chicken or lamb, depending on the day) is amazing. Bonus tip is to call ahead and place your order on the way there.
author: Madhu P.

description: Best ever falafel. Always has been and still is. The hummus is good but is made better by the harrissa or whatever it is they put on it. The baba is better than ok but its really the falafel that puts Truly Med in a category of its own. If you love falafel like I love falafel you'll love Truly Med.
author: Margaret G.

description:
Great flavors.
Reasonable prices.
Great service.
TINY !
author: Jim T.

description:
Life is like a falafel sandwich.

It's exciting, when you first unwrap it, to see perfectly formed layers of texture. Tightly packed, it bursts with intense flavor: sesame, grilled vegetables, creamy tahini and the perfect amount of spice.

But as you get deeper, and down to the depths, things start getting complicated. You lose a bit of the control you once had, along with some of that fervent desire. You rely on things like napkins, and are tested to draw forth experience to avoid potential messiness. 

But once you've tackled the challenges and solidified your position, you'll find the messiest, trickiest parts to be the most flavorful.

Truly.
author: Keane L.

description:
Having gone to college in San Diego, I see Mexican food as the pinnacle of late night dining. Long round of drinking? No problem, if you have access to Cotixan, Roberto's, Santana's, or any of the other delicious taquerias that sprinkle the area. Few things are better than a plate piled high with carne asada fries and a healthy dollop of guac thrown on top.  

Last night, after channeling our inner teenagers by doing a power hour in Dolores Park, some friends and I were STARVING. Not in the "Oh, let's grab some Pringles at the corner store" kind of way, but in the "If someone doesn't feed me soon, I will DESTROY you" kind of way. 

As we headed toward the Mission to hunt down burritos, one of the guys suggested we get Mediterranean instead. I was aghast - Mediterranean? Instead of Mexican? That's blasphemy! Why do you hate America?

Oh. My. Goodness.

I take it back. This is truly the food of the Gods. I had the lamb schwarma - hot, spicy, delicious, and loaded with satisfying meat. It's a bit pricier than the average burrito at $8, but it's absolutely phenomenal. It was the perfect remedy to seven beers in about an hour (we're overachievers).
author: Devon S.

description:
This is not a sit down restaurant.....unless you want to sit outside and have the homeless asking you for your leftovers while trying to sell you yet another copy of Street Sheet, or sit at a stool inside while watching yourself eat in the mirrored wall as the people standing in line bump into you, making the eating process even more unattractive than the messy food already makes it. 

That being said, the food is super cheap and good which makes it taste even better than it probably acutally is. I am anti-french fries in my food, so minus a star for putting fries in a sandwich that should not have fries. I just special order and avoid this snafu commonly found in Mediterranian places on the West coast. 

Buy yourself some food, hold the fries, lock yourself in a room alone with a pile of napkins and go to town.
author: Drue C.

description:
Truly Mediterranean?  What a relief!  Heaven only knows how many places fuse Mediterranean food with Mexican or, heaven forbid, Irish food.  Come on, San Francisco, you can only have Corned Beef & Hummus so many times. 

Not.                 

Aside from their silly name, this place is the bomb.  Oh no, can I make bomb jokes?  (I get so caught up being P.C. that I'm never sure if I have offended someone).  
"Obama is like so popular and my friend likes him, jump on the bandwagon and vote for him, you narrow-minded fools!"  Sorry, had to buy a few friends back. 

Their "special" was the chicken schwarma, my friend ordered one and she devoured the entire thing.   My sampler a.k.a. variety plate a.k.a. "you'll take whatever I throw in front of you and like it" was really good.  Aside from a healthy serving of feta, dolma(s?), hummus & pita bread, it contained the best falafel I have ever had.  Of course, that isn't saying much, but it sure beats the stuff my mom used to cook from a box when she was pretending to be domestic.   

Very limited seating, I wouldn't recommend sitting along the counter inside... instead, I would head outside, wipe down one of the plastic lawn chairs, and keep one hand on your food and the other on your pepper spray.

This is the only place that a homeless guy has offered me money.  He approached and asked me if I wanted a quarter.  So I took it.  Okay, I didn't really take it, but I wanted to.  I like shiny things... it's a curse.  If I wouldn't have been 50% sure that he was going to rip off my ear with his teeth, I would have been all over that coin.  Plus, I didn't want to hurt his feelings..
