I treated my friend to dinner here, like the loaded little lady I am, and after 2 entrees, 2 drinks, and dessert I still didn't break a twenty.

Truly Mediterranean reminds me of what my mother used to say, "It doesn't matter what they look like on the outside, it's what's inside that counts."  

Then again, she also used to say, "remember, you can change Fat, but you can't change Ugly."
author: Janney B.

description:
While feasting on a falafel sandwich the size of your head, you can get your eurostylin' FREAK ON to BARBIE GIRL by AQUA.

I'M A BARBIE GIIIIIRRRRLLLL!!!!!!
EATING FA-LA-FELLLLLLLL!!!!!!
LIFE DRUNKTASTIC!!!!!
IT'S YELPTASTIC!!!

Many many generous stars to the staff here for letting us turn their shop into an impromptu danceclub!

Don't believe me?  Just ask Cassio P!
Don't ask Todd E.  Cuz he don't remember a thang....

ps. this place is ultra cool cuz they also sell arabic tunes!
author: lulu p.

description: We used to always come here from the east bay for falafel but recently we have been disappointed by the horrible customer service and rude employees. We spent nearly $20 on 3 dozen falafel and when we asked for a small container of tahini, the employee told us he couldn't give it to us and said "this is America, nothing is for free" and laughed. We were shocked by the rudeness. While I still love the falafel here, it's certainly not worth the trek over from the east bay and I will not be coming back. Very dissappointed.
author: Randy K.

description: Lamb kabob was good. Falaf not bad. I like the sauce and chunky cucumbers. It's good and you should try the mint yoghurt drink if you like  plain yoghurt with garlic and mint. I was content. They got an extra star for the baklava which was so good.
author: Shabnam A.

description:
The lamb schwarma and chicken schwarma are both amazing, but the falafel deluxe sandwich (with eggplant and fries) is where it's at for me! On top of the good eats, the staff is quick, courteous, and the price is right.

What a yummy spot. Truly Med is a must when visiting Dalva or Delirium.
author: Jill M.

description:
"Do you want it for here or to go?"

I always love being asked that question in a place that seats precisely seven people.

This place mastered the spice blends and sauces to make some excellent wraps.  I think what really makes this place shine is their pistachio baklava.  It's scrumptious.

Truly Mediterranean is a wonderful quick bite establishment.  I almost called it "fast food".  I quickly changed my mind, as that would only invite unfavorable comparisons to terrible national burger chains.
author: Christopher K.

description: The lamb shawerma was great and large enough to split.  Way better than Park Gyros.  And the humus and pita bread was also very tasty.  I would eat here again.
author: Christy L.

description:
LOVE IT! So good. I think I go there maybe once a week? Maybe more? I even eat in there sometimes... Yes, in that tiny space where you have to watch yourself eat -- there's a mirror placed right above the counter there to either make that  place look bigger or so you can make sure you don't have dried tahini on your face when you leave... Their food is so good, and it's a plus that they got a perfect score on their health/cleanliness code check thing (whatever it's called).

Sometimes the guys working there give me funny looks, but whatever... Keep making me the best falafel deluxe with extra hot sauce I've ever had (no, I haven't traveled to the middle east and had TRULY authentic Mediterranean food, but who cares?). Everything I get there is always well spiced, perfectly crisp/cooked, and just yumalicious! I'll keep coming back for as long as you're there, Truly Mediterranean...

Maybe I'll go back right now! Yum...
author: Miss C.

description:
Falafel Deluxe.
Exploded after 4 bites.
It was not tasty.  

I am sad.  

So I write haiku about my sadness.

*************************************
UPDATE: 06/28/2007

Went back and got a lamb shawerma and mediterranean combo plate.  They were good, though the meat was a bit tough and chewy.  But.  I change my mind about this place.  I'm gonna toss a couple extra stars their way.
author: Diana Y.

description:
Been meaning to come here for the longest time.  Finally made it here last Sat and ordered my usual standard by which these places are judged...a falafel wrap.

Just noticed that fellow review Jacquelynne S.'s review pretty much says everything I was going to write.  The falafel wrap was pretty good...messy, but good.  I think it's the way they cut the cucumbers so small, but it was the messiest and hardest to eat falafel wrap I've ever had.  The falafel itself was excellent, moist and nicely green on the inside, although a little bland.  The red hot sauce was thick, pasty, and very one dimensional...it had no depth of flavor.  While it definitely added to the experience (compared to not being there), the red hot sauce wasn't anything to write home about.

The wrap itself was lavash bread (I prefer pita, but lavash is okay) which was grilled just a little too long on the grill (burned part was slightly bitter as a result), but overall was fresh and good.

I too, noticed how full and bloated I felt after eating there.  The portion was nice and generous, but that wasn't it.  Like the other Yelp review said, I normally feel extra healthy whenever I eat Mediterranean food (falafel), but not here.  Weird!  Not sure why that was the case.

Not much seating area, just a small drafty counter down the side with stools to sit on.  Definitely popular on a Saturday afternoon though...the lines went out the door!

The kebabs and other dishes looked really good so perhaps I'll have those instead next time.  In the meantime, my search for the ultimate falafel wrap continues!
author: Roy N.

description:
Well as if I needed any more convincing that food without meat just kinda sucks, yesterday was the final reminder. I'm sorry to any and all vegetarians or vegans or what have you, but I LOVE meat. I would eat it three times a day (and usually do) and if there isn't some kind of meat, poultry or fish in my dish, then it just doesn't feel like a complete meal. 

This was definitely the case yesterday when we came here for a quick bite. I was all excited to order something meaty or lamby, only to be shot down when i asked the cinnamon of death question and was told the only thing they had without cinnamon was a falafel. It then occurred to me that I had never actually had a falafel, so why not try it? I saw the little balls and was hoping they were yummy little fried meatballs, but newp, they were veggie balls. Veggie balls, really, who wants those anywhere near their mouth?

I then found myself getting really sad as I watched the guy make my falafel sammich. I then gazed at my friend's lamb shawarma and got even more sad, knowing her meal was going to kick ass and mine wasn't. I then paid for my meal and went outside with my sammich and took a bite and was kinda surprised. This wasn't half bad...until the second bite when my mind confirmed that there was no meat in this thing and I only got through another few bites without putting it aside and calling it a Truly sad day.

I'm a meat eater, what can I say. I love it and did not love this as a result.
author: Stephy S.

description: OK,  when I moved to the Santa Cruz Area, from San Francisco in 2000, I went through a horrible break-up with  "Truly Mediterranean" (16th and Valencia).  I still have not had a falafel that is better than this.  Even speaking about their falafel, chicken & lamb kababs,  and Chicken Shawerma (Fridays) makes me a little sad.  Nothing really compares to Truly Mediterranean.
author: Geek P.

description:
Hmmm... I thought this was the best place in SF for shawarmas? I came on Friday so I ordered the lone shawarma option, chicken. I watched as they made the wrap.. onions, and a whole lot of em; chicken, tomatoes and parsley, and a few squeezes of tahini sauce. 

Well the tahini was pretty bland, so even the heavy handed squeeze didn't do much for the wrap. The chicken pieces, while moist, weren't very flavorful either. I did like the textural contrast from toasting the wrap, as well as the fresh tomatoes and parsley. The onions though, didn't seem to meld in the wrap, and I typically love onions. They seemed underseasoned, and overwhelmed the wrap as a whole. 

I got hot sauce on the side, and was surprised to find out it tasted like Korean gochucaru flakes made into a paste. House of Falafels in Santa Clara uses Asian chili paste for their hot sauce too, go figure.

Anyhow, I wasn't too impressed and didn't finish the wrap. Maybe the lamb shawarma is better?
author: Derrick V.

description:
The best chicken shawerma (spelling varies, but since they make the best, I spell it like they do) in the universe.  For some reason it's only available on Tuesday and Friday.  I used to drive over from the East Bay and bring them back for lunch.  The other days they have lamb shawerma, which I ordered once and never again.  Don't they understand it's the chicken they excel at?  I totally agree with the comment "I have driven with my knees to scarf down this meal."  In fact, I also add a little improvised placemat to catch any drippings that may seep out the bottom of the foil wrapper.  Oh yeah, their falafel deluxe is good too, maybe the best outside of Israel, but if it's a Chicken Shawerma day I can't be bothered with anything else!

UPDATE: I ate here again after a long absence, and they made me a "shawerrito" -- that's a crappy chicken shawerma made by an all-Mexican staff playing salsa music. It was NOT GOOD. Truly Mediterranean is no longer True or Mediterranean.
author: Ian G.

description: MISSION--I wish these guys would open a sit-down joint. It's the best of its kind that I've found anywhere nearby. Great for on the go. The falafel is exquisite. Tip: an off-menu item, it can be ordered  a la cart. Three falafels and a carrot juice for under $4? You just found yourself a healthy adult happy meal-sized snack.
author: JayBee L.

description:
Holy balls.

A shawerma with extra hot sauce from this little diamond in the rough has saved me from the vengeful wrath of too many Olympias at Double Dutch the night before too many times to count. Walid, the owner, is also quite nice and chatty, if not a just a LITTLE creepy with his rugged middle eastern features coupled with bright blue eyes. Or maybe I'm strangely attracted to him and can't admit that I'm bi. Or maybe I'm rambling.

In conclusion, it's much better than eating cold mac and cheese with your hands then passing out face first in Dolores Park because you're too ruined to drive home.

Eat shawerma!!!! Be happy!!!!
author: Ben P.

description:
Lamb Shawerma- YUMMY AS HELL

Wait- Long, but worth it

Price- Worth it

All of their ingredients in their shawerma was fresh and delicious (:
author: Claudia M.

description:
Chicken kebab with eggplant and extra hummus. I have had other delicious items, but I don't really see the need to venture from the goodness of chicken and sauce and vegetables and magic! wrapped in a grilled-shut piece of lavash. 

My only complaint : sometimes they're right on time (I pick up during my lunch break and don't love spending my entire window waiting for my food), other times, they'll say ten minutes and mean 25.
author: haley d.

description:
Best falafel in the city. I would trade my first-born child for this (Granted, he's not that cute but he is worth more than $4.) 

Eating Truly Med is a take-out experience only, but luckily service is excellent and there are plenty of good bars just steps (over the scum) away that will let you eat inside, which allows for pairing your food with wine (Casanova  or 500 Club), beer (Killowatt) or a marini (Blondie's). Truly Med does it right---lavash. I will not have it any other way. Pita pockets will not suffice. The grill is a nice touch, creating the perfect crispy pouch of scumptiousness. It's perfect. Trust me, I'm a falafel whore.

My second choice for falafels is Gyro King across from the main branch library in Civic Center.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
If I could give them ten stars, I would ... they are absolutely outstanding!

Recently due to health issues, I've started to religiously heed my doctor's warnings regarding my allergies to wheat and dairy.  When I walked into Truly Mediterranean and saw patron after patron ordering shawerma, feta sandwiches and fresh pita bread, I just wanted to weep.  How could I possibly satisfy myself without warm pita bread and hunks of delicious feta?

I explained my allergies to the guy who took my order, and he built me the most incredible combination plate.  Since I couldn't eat the pita, tabbouleh and feta that normally come with the combo plate, he allowed me to choose grilled tomatoes, grilled eggplant, dolma and extra falafel as substitute components.  My carton was heaped with fresh hummus, babaganoush, falafel, cucumber salad, seasoned onions, grilled veggies, falafel, dolma and tahini for only $7.50!!

Go there now ... this was the best tasting meal I've had all month! Oh yeah ... the olive oil that they use to drizzle over their food is so fragrant and flavorful that it could be consumed by the glass.  YUM!!!
author: Jenny K.

description:
If I could give Truly Med 6 stars, I would. Amazing that such good food can come from a hole-in-the-wall togo place. Have you seen the awards wall? It's amazing.

Another thing that makes me love Truly Med: I ducked in the other day because I was absolutely starving but also meeting people elsewhere for dinner 30 minutes later. I asked if it was possible for me to get a side of something---I didn't see that on the menu. The guy asked me what I wanted, prepared a little side of falafel for me with sauce and all, and gave it to me on the house. SO NICE!
author: Laura B.

description:
Best Falafel wrap ever. It's not really cheap like some other options in the Mission, but you definitely get your money's worth in portion size. The place is also a little tight and cramped, so it's good for takeout. 

The food definitely caters to the the more tangy-friendly palate (like mine), so be prepared. I haven't tried the meat options, so I can't speak for that, but this is my favorite Mediterranean place in SF so far :)

Try it! You won't be disappointed!
author: Ryan V.

description:
A bit of a whole in the wall, but you come here for the food, not the atmosphere.  There's a tiny counter with stools if you must eat-in, but getting it to go here is the way to go.

Delish falafel, fairly accomodating employees. Prices are pretty good too.
author: Lea B.

description:
Truly Med: Lamb shwarma with hot sauce?

Me: Abso-fuckin'-lutely.
author: Cathy H.

description: I don't know why I never heard of this place, but everyone has been raving on Yelp! so I dropped by Saturday night. I had the falafel deluxe with hot sauce and it was fantastic. My only complaint: no seating and no one warned me on Yelp!, come on guys! It was freezing so we decided to grab and take home rather than sit outside on the two plastic chairs. I'm going to have to go back to try some of the other items on the menu. Thanks gang, great place!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I like to pick up a side of falafel and take them home to eat with healthy pita and my favorite hummus (If you read my reviews, I am picky). This place gives me 6 falafels to go with hot sauce for 2 bucks! and they are good! 

They have also been very friendly to me anytime I have been there!
author: Kiera H.

description:
How good is the falafel at this place? So good that while I was waiting in line, my laptop fell out of my backpack and crashed onto the hard tile floor, and nothing broke. Still works perfectly; I'm typing on it now, as I type. That doesn't directly speak to the quality of the food here, yet it is indicative of the mystical halo of goodness that encircles this fine purveyor of Mediterranean delights.

Seriously, the falafel is amazing. Watching the friendly wait-staff crush those little fried balls makes me feel exactly like I am about to eat some fucking delicious food, because I am. I recommend getting extra hot sauce (it's not very spicy, but the flavor is boy-yoy-yoing!) and going light on the tahini (they sometimes have a heavy hand and it ruins the structural integrity of the wrap).

The lamb is equally tasty, but I feel like the falafel steals the show, and you feel this too, in the bottom of your falafel-feeling heart.

If you head there a few minutes before closing, you might walk out with a paper bag full of warm, orphaned falafel balls that would otherwise be thrown to the gods. This happened to my girlfriend once, for real.
author: Max H.

description:
Unbelievable great falafel sandwiches.  And not only are they tasty, but they hold their own against size and weight to any burrito in the mission.

Great priced as well.  Not a lot of seating, sometimes you can score the single table just outside.
author: Vinnie L.

description:
Mary had a little lamb and so she made a shawarma. Mmm...shawarma. Thank you Mary.

Food - excellent (Stick with the lamb. T & Th they serve chicken)
Ambiance - cramped
Service - good - nice people.
author: J F.

description:
I eat here 3 times a week. 
Go Deluxe or go home
Plus they take Amex.
author: Joe G.

description: Fabulous Falafel wrap.  Super crunchy, with lots of fresh veggies... and it's huge!  I usually have enough for 2 meals.  Yum.
author: Anne A.

description:
I would hop on a BART train into the City just to go to this place.  Well within walking distance of the 16th and Mission station.

It's a small place with a couple of tables.  Reminded me of places in the East Coast.  Walk in, order, wait for your food, pick up your food leave.  If you want to eat there you can, but you don't stay long just because you're there to eat.  No nonsense.

I ordered a lamb shawarma and had to endure smelling it on the way home before I could dig in.  It had the right balance of flavors and spiciness.  The portion was too big for me, but I had it for lunch the next day and it was still deliciousness wrapped in a package.

They must make their food with crack (not that I've had crack) because I immediately wanted to go back and eat there for every single meal.
author: Cathleen T.

description: When I get a lamb shawerma craving, nothing else will do.  Got to get it extra spicy, otherwise it's a little bland.  Out the door for less than $10 is also part of its awesomeness.
author: Julie T.

description:
I had bookmarked this place a while ago after reading my friend Jenny K's review, but it took me a while to go there.  After my meal last night, I immediately regretted not going much sooner -- and I can't wait until my next visit!

We split a combination platter and a falafel pita.  The combination platter was so delicious - pita, hummus, cucumber salad, tabouleh, feta, dolmas, falafel, some more sauces.  After we polished that off we were almost full, but we still had a big falafel pita waiting for us (good thing we didn't order two!).  As good as it was, we could only finish half - the portions are huge here!  At just under $20 for two and a half meals (I took the rest of the falafel home - no way was I letting something so good go to waste), this place is quite a good deal.    

The guys working there are nice, too.  They wiped down the counter for us without our asking, and when I got a bottle of water from their fridge, they gave me a colder one.
author: DD B.

description:
The SHAWERMA here speaks for itself.  So I'll let it talk:
SHAWERMA SHAWERMA SHAWERMA.
Here's a Shawerma haiku:
dancing on a spit
fat drips onto tomatoes
sizzling lamb tease

[psst, prices have gone up recently, but it's still hands down the best shawerma in the city]
author: Fong L.

description:
Such a pleasure to recommend this spot, a recent discovery for me being relatively new to SF. My friend, an entrenched native who knows nothing but good eats and swears by this place dragged me in here one Friday and omg = amazing treat.  Although I won't eat any red meat like lamb, the hummus here is unreal.  Best I've ever had.  One bite will have you in a happy haze of palate ecstasy with its creamy, tangy supreme deliciousness, wow....   
Their Chicken Shawerma is prepared almost lovingly with broiled tomatoes and seasoned onions in this garlic yoga sauce. YES, child.   And the giant portion sizes are definitely more than one meal. 

Also* no sleepin on the sweets either, everyone loves the baklava but one has to ask about the chocolaty delight they sell right next to that.  

Very affordable especially considering you will have leftovers to enjoy.
author: Michelle S.

description: Love this place ... from shwerma to the very nice woman at the register make me drive across town to get this hand held delight.
author: Scott G.

description:
The men behind the counter seemed pretty serious, and I didn't want to bother them with any obnoxious questions.  So, flashing my biggest, braciest smile (as an apology for my lack of knowledge), I quickly asked, "what's the difference between the Falafel and Falafel Deluxe?"

"Falafel Deluxe has potato and eggplant."

Yes, they were serious; serious in a ready-to-make-the-food-now kind of way.   There was no time to waver.  I knew that the Falafel itself was going to be enormous, but who was I to deny the siren call of eggplant? And for just a dollar more? The devils!

"Ooh, I'll have a Falafel Deluxe!"

Quickly they worked, slapping together a flatbread sandwich that grew larger and larger by the second.  My stomach grumbled - in desire or protest?  Moments later I was back out on 16th with my prize in tow, and I had only spent $7.65.  That's pretty cheap for something that was larger than my stomach.

Delicious?  I had convinced myself before beginning my eating odyssey that I could only possibly eat half, but as I chowed through the wrap, my brain kept saying, "no, just ONE more bite of the part with the falafel!  No no, now just ONE more bite of the part with the eggplant!  Now, come on, gotta have ONE more taste of that falafel!"

Suddenly it was over. All that was left was the tahini sauce, coating my hands like a trophy.
author: Mariah M.

description: Go on Tues or Friday and get the chicken schawerma.  It rocks the house.  Definitely one of my faves - wish they still had their other locations!
author: Gene X.

description:
I came across this ethnic conundrum on my way to the Roxie theater next door. Why is it that most places like this get labeled (or even label themselves) as Mediterranean, while the food is actually Middle Eastern? Is the average American falafel craver slightly uncomfortable that there may be an IED in your wrap? Not to mention that your order is served up by a bunch of energetic Latin-Americans, adding to the Babylonian confusion. 

Either way, if you're looking for a quick and filling meal at the buzzing corner of Valencia and 16th, the stuff in this ethnic melting pot looks fresh, is served with a smile, and is quite delicious.
author: Michiel D.

description:
I had been looking forward to this place because I'd heard really good things about it.  I am so pissed I even went to this place now. 

I came in with three other girlfriends.  Two of my friends went straight up to the guy at the "Pick Up" section of the counter and ordered their stuff.  When I went up to the guy, who was obviously less excited to take my order, he directed me to the guy chillin over at the "Order" section of the counter.  The guy took his time finishing his conversation before taking my order and acting like I was wasting his fucking time.  Then, all the employees started bitching and moaning in Spanish about bitches and cunts and fucking them.  

The falafels we ordered were only okay, but even if they weren't, I'm never spending my money there again.
author: Elle L.

description:
I don't go to the Mission much, but ended up at Truly Mediterranean after working out at the Potrero Hill 24 Hour Fitness on 16th and Bryant.  I used the yelp-for-iphone application because I was interested in finding the nearest mediterranean food to the gym, and it led me straight down 16th street.

I'm doing the low-carb thing til I lose about 5 more pounds, and the guy who prepared my order was extremely accommodating in offering the Kebab "sandwich" as a "plate," and he even offered hummus instead of the bread they use to wrap the sandwich.

Another thing, the Kefta Kebab was the most delicious, biggest portion I have found in San Francisco.  Normally priced from $9-14 elsewhere around the city, I found it very fairly priced at $5.99.  I live in North Beach and consider it a lucky day when you can find a meal under $10. Last week I went back 4 days in a row !!

Beware, seating is very limited.  Be prepared to take your order to go.  It won't stop me, though.  I'm planning to go every day after work next week as well.

Note to low carb dieters:  As you know, the max you can lose a week with sensible, low carb eating is about 3 pounds.  Having the kefta kebab plate 4 days in a row helped me achieve that - it fits the diet plan PERFECTLY.  That doesn't mean I'll stop eating there after I lose weight !!
author: Max G.

description:
Being short on time before a show, this was the perfect bet for some good, healthy food on the run. I'm always in search of great eggplant dishes, but most of the time this means that you get it cooked in heavy oil-- and as good and comforting as it tastes, it  always leaves me feeling a little like a lumbering greasy sloth.

I think I can safely say that this is the best pure and simple eggplant I've ever had here: it was tender (even the skin) perfectly seasoned with herbs and olive oil and no bitterness whatsoever-- it was healthy and light and just amazing...its really that good.

I also had the chicken kabob wrap which was equally awesome: well-cooked and seasoned chicken with some kick ass hot sauce.  The damn thing was so huge that I could muster maybe 1/3 of that sucker-- so you can't go wrong with the portions here. 

The food is so pungent that my car still reeks like a Greek deli kitchen-- but it was so well-worth it...
author: NaNa M.

description:
TRULY MED TIPS

1. Call in your order for a shawerma. 

2. Ask for hot sauce for a nice burn

3. Park at the bus stop in front of the Roxie for pick up and go.
author: christopher r.

description:
I don't wanna raise my hackles every time one of my friends says "oh, this is the best". I wanna go try their place and come away with my fingers licked to the nibs, stomach satiated and even, on occasion, ebullient.

So.

This place is super small; it has a wall with a slim bar and stools and a minuscule outside eating area. Take out would be a good option, esp.if there was a scenic destination involved. 

I got the Falafel Deluxe w/out fried potatoes sub hummus. It was what I wanted, and when I asked for no potatoes what the man behind the counter suggested. I appreciated his mind reading customer satisfaction skills. Er, ok, I am prolly not the only one, I realize. 

The wrap was huge, I had to save the tail to wag later. For $7 bucks and some change, it was def a meal that didn't leave you hungry. I like how they grill the lavash at the end and the eggplant was soft but not burnt. The hot sauce was medium in my opinion and the hummus was bland. But in a package all together with the falafel, it worked. 

So.

For speed, cost, size/value I will give four stars, but for total flavor satisfaction, I am holding back on that last star.
author: Miel H.

description:
Now this is the kind of falafel sandwich I love. They really do it right here. Probably best falafel I've ever had. Husband would agree and may even say that it's better than the stuff he had while visiting Israel.

Now since I can eat like a truck driver, their sandwich sizes don't scare me, but be forewarned... they're huge! These yummy sandwiches have the right amount of spiciness with yummy falafel on fresh lavash bread. 

This location (there used to be a larger location in North Beach) is a tiny, tiny hole-in-the wall so it's best to get it to go. Or, if the outside tables are open, eating out there is fine as long as you don't mind the urban scenery (which may or may not include homeless people walking by).
author: Kimi W.

description: Truly confusing is more like it! Absolutely one of the worst places I have ever eaten at. There is nothing mediterranean about it at all. The meat in the "schwarma" is overcooked and the the overall package is tasteless; leaving every single bite with confused thoughts. Unfortunately, the buck doesn't stop there...we paid an extra $9 for a combo plate...bottom line don't get it. Their version of bulgur is simply shredded parsley next to literally raw cucumbers. Did they want me to go home and finish preparing the salad for them? The falafel was burned on the outside and raw inside..disgusting. All in all, save yourself the trip to this pretend want-to-be mediterranean imbiss. Two thumbs DOWN!
author: Tia N.

description:
it was a dark and stormy night. I'd just finished watching a documentary on sandwiches and as soon as it was over, I was aching for a falafel.  The rain and late hour kept me from going out and picking one up, so I spent the rest of the night dreaming of where I could get a crispy falafel in tender lavash the next day.  I knew the joint near my place wouldn't suffice, as I'd seen a cockroach near the water pitcher one time and ever since then, just hadn't had the urge to go. I know, I know, lots of places have cockroaches, but once I saw one I guess my brain just lost all taste for that particular place. 

Having lived in the Mission for 8 years prior to my new neighborhood, I knew Truly Mediterranen would totally hit the spot for my craving.  Their schwermas are great, and the falafel is fried just perfect.  So the next day, I trekked over to Truly Med for lunch.  I ordered my falafel deluxe, grabbed a ginger beer and sat down to wait for my wrap.

Unfortunately, the next few minutes will forever remain burned in my brain and I will very likely NEVER return to this place.  

I sat at the counter casually looking through the mirror at the workers behind me.  Apparently, the tahini sauce ran out, so one of them went to the back to grab the bucket they keep it in.  After pouring the refill, this guy USED HIS BARE FINGER TO WIPE THE RIM, letting the tahini slide off HIS BARE FINGER back into the bucket. 

Sure, he might have washed his hands before doing that, or he could have just been holding his warts-encrusted member in the bathroom. Who's to say? The point is, no respectful cook would ever do that let alone where everyone can see.

I won't tell you whether or not I ate my falafel deluxe after that, or whether I licked at the tahini that dripped onto the back of my hand.  But I will say that unless I'm stumbling drunk on 16th and craving a falafel, I will NEVER GO BACK TO TRULY MEDITERRANEAN.

Next time, do that in the back, bro.
author: N. L.

description:
I honestly didn't know that I liked falafel....til today.....YUM!

My experience with falafel is that it is usually squishy, something I don't like so much.

Truly Med's falafel is great!  Crispy on the outside, packed full of flavor on the inside.  Sesame seeds on the crispy outside adds a lovely flavor complexity I didn't know falafel could have.

The overall Mediterranean plate I got is pretty good, but I find the babaganoush to be a little oily, and the dolmas are not my favorite of all time.  But if I have a hankerin' for Mediterranean food, I'll definitely consider this place an option.
author: Jane A.

description:
Smack my ass and call me a cab as i am certainly walking home after eating here!  I was sooo stuffed i felt like a porn tar after a weekend Vegas "Adult Entertainment" conference.

I know we all can eat a lot, but seriously folks, split the Swarama, but this allows you to have a couple of Dalmas and at least one pasticcio Baklava.  Oh, I am drooling just writing about it.  The sauce is smooth with a bit of lime mixed in so it does not taste like the usual pasty spunk you find at other falafel places. 

There is a line table in the place, but for your sake take it to the park and have a picnic with a tall beer.  Oh ya, and don't skimp on the beer, myfriend.  Step up and have a bit of taste and subtle culture and pitch in for a Tiger beer or an Indian beer which was made for such a spicy feast.
author: Jai D.

description:
Best Shwarma and falafel in town - hands down. All others are immitations, don't believe the hype

The others get  zero stars, Ze-Ro, nada, the big doughnut
author: Robert v.

description:
I don't know if I would call this place cheap. My chicken shawerma was flavorful (with real grilled tomatoes, and lots of cilantro), but it also cost me $7.50. I wasn't unsatisfied by any means, but beware that this ain't no $3 gyro joint. 

Go on a sunny day and eat at one of the two small tables set up on the sidewalk. Oh, and don't forget to add in the feta cheese. It really makes a difference!
author: Dave K.

description:
Ok, nothing either great nor awful.  It was very middle of the road and I think I'd probably just go to Ali Baba's over Truly Mediterranean the next time I want falafel in the Mission.

Ali Baba's is far from perfect but it is decent and for the same price the falafel is bigger and you get fries and eggplant.  But Truly Mediterranean is closer to me.  It's a toss up.  I'd probably rather get more food at a cheaper price at Ali Baba's.

ps - I don't know what Rommy's talking about.  Us Jews eat falafel too.  We love it, and we don't wish to kill the west.  Something has gone sour in someone's Tahini it seems...
author: daniel m.

description:
You're at home. It's 7:30 p.m.  Rather suddenly, you're like, "sh1t, I am hungry." And you don't want to cook because you're too busy / tired / hung over. So you walk out toward 16th in search of quick, easy, tasty grub.

You could sit down in a restaurant, but you're too busy / tired / hung over for that, too.

You could go to McDonald's. Wretch.

Or you could get a tasty, consistently good falafel or shawarma from Truly Mediterranean. Their food is good, their service is fast, and you always know what you're going to get. Which, when you're in a rush, and you just want something easy and good, is important. Because "variety" of the "crappy experience" type is generally unwanted when you're too busy / hung over / tired.

Favorite part of the falafel? The falafel ball thing. Sometimes I order the plate so I can enjoy it separately. And the small cubed cucumber.

p.s. - their health inspection score was 100. The sh1ts are not what you want when you're busy / hung over / tired.

p.p.s. - try their baklava. I'm not sure they make it themselves, but it's well done.
author: Matt M.

description: If you want one of the best hole in the wall places...this is it!!! I dream about the food...if that tells you anything! Hah! The prices are very reasonable! ($5.00 to $7.00) It doesn't get any better than that! It's cheaper than fast food and a lot healthier!!! The Chicken Shawerma and the Falafel Deluxe is what it's all about!!! I don't eat Lamb but friends have told me it's to die for! Not really a place to sit and eat at....very limited seating. This is a more take out type of place. This is the one place to not miss out on!
author: Matt C.

description: Good when you're there, good when the half-you-couldn't-eat-of-this-massive-Middle-Eastern-burrito (that alone makes me sooo uncultured, HAH) turns up as dinner. I'd come here again, and I'd probably bring friends. Middle Eastern friends, even!
author: Camille T.

description: Besides Med Wraps in Palo Alto, this is my favorite Mediterranean wraps place in the Bay Area.  The lamb wrap is delicious and tender, and the falafels are to die for.  The only problem is it's a hole-in-the-wall with no real seating areas.  Great for a pickup-and-go type lunch/dinner.
author: Kryzak K.

description:
I have classes at the Centro del Pueblo down the street and I love the location due to the only fact its so near Truly Medierranean.  My classmate told me to grab a shewerma there.  best advice ever.

i tried both the chicken shewerma and lamb.  i'm indifferent with the lamb. the chicken is awesome, it's finger licking good.  you can scarf it down in one sitting even if it's so fulfilling by the time you're done with half of it.  my roommate doesn't like cucumbers, so its best if you ask no cucumber salad instead of having to pause and pick it out.  

the falafel deluxe is also good if you're a vegetarian, but i think i'll be sticking to the chicken shewermas from now on.  ORANGINA with your meal ftw (for the win!)
author: Janina U.

description:
All I've had so far is Truly's Falafel Deluxe, and deluxe it is! This fabulous tasting wonderment is gigantic, stuffed with grilled onion, cucumber, tahini, spicy pepper spread, falafel, eggplant, and french fries. I mean, is there really a better thing to eat while drunk (or just really hungry)? There's always the off chance, but this is pretty close to street food perfection. I order the Deluxe sans potato, substituting for babaganough (smoked eggplant spread) instead, and without the potatoes it's insanely filling. They wrap that giant sucker up and put it on their hot grill for a few moments to slightly char the lavash and heat everything up. 

Nice service and brilliant food. If only it wasn't so hard to find parking at this hip corner of the Mission.
author: Shannon F.

description:
I once was in here, contemplating a chicken shawarma.

"I wonder how fresh their chicken is," I thought.

Then I heard a chicken cluck in the kitchen. 

True story.

Needless to say they have amazing food.
author: Mark G.

description: Chicken kebab. Perfectly grilled. Spiced just right. Wonderful. AND SO MUCH GREAT FOOD FOR SUCH A GREAT PRICE.
author: Bernie S.

description:
Falafel Deluxe with hot sauce + extra tahini sauce + roasted tomatoes = heaven.

Seriously, I eat here at least twice a month--if not, I go insane.  For a rolling good time, take your shwarma or falafel and a pack of cards then head into Dalva's next door for a beer drinkin', poker playin' Mediterranean feast.

The food is fast and tasty, the staff is personal and funny, and the size of the joint only enhances its charm.
author: Kat P.

description:
shawarma, shwarma, shawerma ....however you want to spell it, it's good here!

I've had one of the best lamb shawermas here. I've had shawermas at a lot of different restaurants and none (so far) have measured up to this one. I'm a semi-lamb fan, so it didn't taste gamey to me at all. The lamb pieces were juicy and full of flavor. Not one dry piece. The wrap is tightly packed w/also tomatoes and vegetables so you won't make a huge mess. It's a good size and I was only able to eat half of it. This is definately not a dine in place so take it to go and eat it at a local park or in your own home.

Will be back here several more times!
author: Veronica H.

description:
Best Chicken Shawarma in the city! (But they only have chicken Tuesdays and Fridays- so really 4.5 stars but I rounded up...)  And the hot sauce they add is amazing- full of so much flavor, but not super spicy!

This is the only falafel, I'll eat!  Moist and flavorful, never dry and bland.

Excellent fresh carrot juice, they make it when you order it.

mmmm, mouth watering!
author: Paige B.

description: Messy,  flavorful, affordable, craveable.  I want you now.
author: Sarah G.

description:
This is a good place to get a quick bite. Huge quantity and low price. It is a really small place. They do have some stools and some counter space for customers to sit on but I would recommend that you pick up your food and eat it at home.

Very nice people and they cook your food with a lot of care. The size of their wraps is HUGE so starve yourself a bit before you head out to this place.
author: Shefali S.

description:
I know how it goes.  

You're hungry.

You're in the Mission.

You're thinking "I need a burrito!"

I'd like to take this opportunity to direct your attention to a burrito of another type... a delicious lamb shawerma.  I came and got one and was not disappointed, it was consistently delicious, meaty and about the size of any of  the titanic burritos I would've normally been seeking in the Mission.

Truly Mediterranean is definitely on my radar for a quick mission meal.
author: Steven R.

description:
I must say, I was pretty disappointed by this place. But, perhaps because I have REALLY high expectations for my favorite cuisine - Mediterranean food!...and good service.

Had just spent the entire day at the SF Pride parade and had yelped this place in advance thinking it would be super cool to hit up this "hole in the wall gem" as many people seemed to have reviewed for dinner. So, I dragged my fellow foodie date with me across town to try it out. 

And I kinda felt guilty afterwards making him walk so far because the place was not as cool as I hopped it would be -- perhaps Yelp hyped it up too much =(.

FOOD: We ordered the combo plate (falafel + hummus + baba ganoosh + tabolleh + dolma + warm pita) and chicken gyro (extra spicy).  Pretty tasty and decently portioned considering the cheap price (about $15 total for both dishes), but I can definitely say I've had better. 

AMBIANCE/STAFF: Mmm...I'll have to be completely blunt: I was pretty appalled when one of the staff started feelin up on one of his customers/good friends. They were probably just playing around or maybe drunk, but uh....yea. Hard to enjoy the food when immature/crude activity is going on about 2 feet behind you. Not cool.

However, the elder staff member who wasn't so busy squeezing boobs on the side was pretty nice -- he was kind enough to cut our wrap in half seeing that we were going to share. One of the two stars goes just to him!

Anyway, over all...I'd have to say this is the first time Yelp reviews has failed me. 

For those of you who truly want to discover some REAL tucked away Mediterranean food places, Wally's in Emervyille is the place to go! Check out my review for details. For a sit-down place, hit up La Med in Berkeley on College Ave. Or if you ever find yourself in Long Beach, CA...hit up George's Greek Cafe.
author: Gail N.

description:
Yesterday marked my 3rd visit to Truly Med since I was first introduced a month ago. Credits go to the BF who have been frequenting here for quite some time. 

The first time there, I ordered a lamb shawerma and chose to eat it there--on the cushioned stools, facing the mirror. Being a complete newbie, I didn't realize that there was only one correct end to open the tin foil. I opened mine from the bottom (wrong side).  Just when I was about the dive in, the cashier quickly caught my attention, and rushed over to re-wrap my shawerma with tin foil. The top (correct end) is open, you see, and had the cashier not saved me, I would have been left with bits of lamb, yogurt sauce, onions, etc. falling onto on my lap. Great service--even from behind the counter! The shawerma was delicious with just the right amount of seasoning and tenderness of the meat. 

The second time, I got the lamb shawerma again. Opened it up from the top end. No mishaps there except the mess I made from devouring the thing.

Yesterday, my third time, I was lucky enough to go on a chicken day (Tuesdays and Fridays). Got the chicken shawerma (with hot sauce, of course). Once again, lived up to expectations..and in fact, I like the chicken more than the lamb. Need to make a mental note to visit more frequently on chicken days. 

Make sure to get the hot sauce! Always. 

And remember, even though this place is in the Mission, the shawerma isn't a burrito. That means...there is only one correct end to eat it from.
author: Rona J.

description:
I have had the Falafal Regular sandwich here twice now, and it's pushing right up against divine. This is a tubular sandwich that stands on its end. Who wouldn't love that? The falafel balls are flavorful and not greasy, the diced cucumber plentiful and bright, the sauce earthy. Next time I'm going to go without the onions, as they are a little overwhelming and lingering. Not only is the sandwich itself amazing, but the packaging is perfectly designed to eat anywhere, for instance at the Roxie next door while watching a movie, with minimal mess.

Next up: Shawarma!
author: Julie N.

description:
I can't tell you how many times I have stumbled in to Truly M. drunk and starving! Well, almost as many as I have sober (so i can tell you it is STILL good!)

If you looking for good Mediterranean food, this is it! If you are looking for a place to sit down and enjoy your food, this is NOT the place! I think there might be two tables...outside.

Try my favorite, the shwarma (kind of a middle eastern burrito) with lamb. If you are not a cute cuddly lamb eater, then have the chicken shwarma only served tuesdays and fridays. For the kosher and animal friendly people there is the equally good falafel. Also worth a try, combo plate with hummus, tabbouleh, dolmas, and some other delicious goodie i am forgetting...oh yeah, and of course pita!
author: Molly W.

description:
TAKE OUT ONLY - TAKE OUT ONLY
Dinner for two $18 at this hole in the wall
We braved the super narrow eating area (and got a back cramp in the process trying to twist around not touching other people)
An occasional, exceptionally smelly homeless person may wander in while you are eating.
Mexican children playing jungle gym in the corner on giant mama and baby stroller kick you every minute or so
You can also gander at the workers there, pretty much a modern day version of indentured servants.
Those better be enough reasons for TAKE OUT ONLY
author: G K.

description:
WOW! Ok, let me say that this place rocks. Like, what the hell?! It's a hole-in-the-wall kinda place, and I seriously kept thinking, "Why did he take me here? Why did he take me here?!" It just doesn't look like a typical "taste-o-rific" place. But then I was watching them make me my schwarma. That was kinda cool. AND THEN! I ate it.

HOLY FREAK MOTHER OF A HOLY MAN WOW!

It seriously rocked my socks off. That's how good it was. And I was thinking, "Well, I don't think I'm going to like this." But I did. I am honestly telling everyone to go here when they are in the neighborhood. It's only downfall is that it's so close to Andalu. But, even with that bad geographical error, it's getting a 5.

Rock on Truly Med! :)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
In a word: Eh. 

I was hungover, watching football, drinking beer, and hungry. In other words, easy to please. I got the falafel wrap delux. The grilled aspect was nice, but all in all it felt completely uninspired -- really dry, not all that flavorful. Even the hot sauce was boring. In no way memorable. 

The meat might be good, but I wouldn't know.
author: Ian H.

description:
Truly Mediterranean= Truly Heaven.

The only reason I came across this gem is because I have a friend who lives a block away. And anytime I stay at his place, I pretty much live off of Truly Mediterranean. They're not your typical "kabob and pita" place- they make these amazing wraps with either chicken or lamb shwarma or the BEST falafel (and I HATE falafel). They wrap it with tomatoes, feta, lettuce, onions, Tzatziki-like sauce... I'm getting hungry just thinking about it! Even though parking is rough, call in your order ahead of time and double park. Thats what I do.

And they're open til 12 I believe- so if you're in the Mission getting drunk, DO NOT spend 4 bucks on a disgusting Bacon-wrapped hot dog. Yes, they smell good! But they're NOTHING compared to the best wraps in town!
author: Lauren A.

description: Bomb diggy. I'd eat lunch here every day. 100% health inspection
author: Carlos L.

description: Meh. I was really excited to try this place after coming back from Europe and craving some doner kebabs. Every random place we tried throughout Europe tasted better...my shawerma here was disappointing, bland, and kinda mushy.
author: Lainy C.

description: I'm usually not a huge fan of chicken shwerma (I'm all about the original), but they only had chicken shwerma the night I went.  But the chicken shwerma (with hot sauce, of course) was awesome.  And the price is right!
author: Wendy L.

description: This was one of my staple foods when I was a bouncer at Liquid in the back in 1999/2000.  I have been gluten free for health reasons but did eat here when taking a friend from out of town on a tour of my old stomping grounds.  It was worth it!  Make your Shawerma deluxe and add eggplant for the best shawerma ever!  I want one of the lamb rotisseries in my house!
author: Chris D.

description: i tried the lamb shwawerma, and i have to say that unfortunately it was nothing special. It was just alright, I would get it again, but I would never have the cravings it for. You definitely get your money's worth, they give you a nice sized burrito looking things, and it was around $8-9. But the taste is nothing special, kind of boring. Not bad if you are in a hurry to grab food. There are not many seats for you to sit, so be prepared that you're gonna have to to-go your food!
author: Beryl B.

description:
Some of the best Middle Eastern food outside of Detroit. The falafel, schwarma and dolmas are great, and the only bad parts are how small this location is, that there's no bathroom, there are no sides of French Fries (like the old Haight store) and that it's in the Mission. Okay, only sorta joking on the last one. 

And, well, that the Haight location is gone because of evil landlords.

But, if you like Middle Eastern, this is the place to come. And, they are nice guys that remember you and what you order.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
their schawarmas are so good, it makes you want to takea diaretic to make space for another one.  Yes the store is a bit small, but hey, its right next to the BART. feel free to eat it onboard, cause everyone else does.  

their hummus is pretty solid as well.  not actually solid, cause that would be gross.  and very hard to dip your pita in.
author: Huyness D.

description: Simply the best shawerma and falaffel in the bay area.  All food and ingredients are incredibly fresh and flavorful.
author: John C.

description:
Pretty bad ass Lamb and Chicken Schwarma's here!  
Chicken is offered Tuesdays and Fridays only I think.  

The Schwarma's here are great.  They add spiced cucumbers and onions which add a nice crunchy texture.  The meat is pretty lean and damn flavorful.  Best off, the tahini sauce is perfect with a nice mix of hot sauce.  Best part is how they toast the wrap which tops off the nice mixture of soft oozing meat/sauce with the crunchy texture of the veggies and wrap. 

Place-Hole in the wall with no space.  These are my fav spots though!

Price- With tax, around $8.50.  Kinda pricey for this area.  But worth it. 

Parking-Not the easiest area to park.  Mostly metered parking.
author: Chase F.

description:
Meh. There's better places to get shawarma & falafel.

I got the Falafel Deluxe (falafel, eggplant), the SO got the Lamb Shawarma. Both were served quickly and both were enormous and filling. The variety of ingredients is good but flavor is lacking. Lamb was chewy.

There was a sign that said "Try our mint ginger yogurt drink!" so we did. Meh.

Locals tell me that this place used to be great but it's gone downhill a little. I'd have to agree.
author: Kevin H.

description: I land at SFO, I take a cab/drive/Bart here to catch up on missed time enjoying the worlds finest..... it is always entertaining for others to watch me down 3 lamb shwarmas in a row & wash trhem down with Orangina!!!
author: Sean O.

description: lamb shwarma and falafel nevermind my spelling.. came here to try the 7 x 7 item lamb schwarma ... it was good but not as good as those freshly fried fallafel balls.  WOW!  they were one of the best ones I've ever had....hot, warm fluffy on the inside not dense like most places.. this place actually might be better than the falafel king on divisadero!  the hummus is freshly made and tastes very authentic and delicious. !
author: Margie C.

description:
Best FALAFEL DELUXE.  Period.  I get one every Friday for lunch.

And people LURVE the shawarmas.  How am I supposed to spell that?  I see it every which way.

Who cares.  EAT ONE!  From Truly Med.
author: Dwayne A.

description:
Truly Med is the bomb! this place would is border line on an A-OK b/c there is much space to eat the food and parking is terrible. Like the man who gave the tips I totally agree with him. I have them in my phone, call it in and park at the bus stop and run out and grab it to go. I wish they would expand and have a sit down restaurant, they once did in North Beach but it closed down a while ago, not sure how it wasn't a huge hit....

My favorite items on their menu is the Chicken Shewerma, actually it might be the only thing I have ever ordered from there.
author: Bobby B.

description: Love this place.  When we want good mediterranean food at work, we drive to here.  Mind you, we work in Daly City and will drive all the way there.  I've tried a lot of their dishes.  Some things I didn't like just because of my preference like tabouleh, I just never liked that.  But as for shawarma, kabob, etc.?  Good stuff over here!  Love their falafel, fresh and tasty!!!!!  hummus is awesome-ly good, although I prefer mine more lemon-y, but I know each place makes their own different.  Dolma was good too, the best I've had!  Feta sandwich was good too!  It's a small place, but workers there are friendly and fast.  I'm not expect with mediterranean food, but this one is a winner!
author: Claire J.

description: Stopped by the Mission after a work meeting and hit up Truly Med for lunch.  Had a regular falafel and eat there. Falafels are very fresh and are always just cooked.  Best is they grill the falafel wrap after making it.  I find this heats up the cucumber and tahini striking the perfect temperature balance.  Be sure to get the hot sauce.  Only  negative is the place is very narrow and tight if you eat there.  Grab to go.
author: Eric Z.

description:
Truly Mediterranean's all right...definitely not bad, but definitely not mind-blowingly good.  Then again, you're hard-pressed to find good, cheap Mediterranean food in the city so this place isn't a shabby option.

I had a kefta kabob and they definitely didn't skimp on the lamb which was nice.  Plus, the spicy sauce added a nice kick (but oddly, reminded me of Korean food).

Maybe next time I'll try the falafel...that's what all the other 999 Yelpers seem to be yelping about!
author: Ellen B.

description:
Truly Mediterranean has some of the best Schwarma and Falafel wraps I have had in my life.

They make it fresh and they make it fast.  Also, all wraps are decently priced at about $6-$8 and a single wrap should fill you up completely - if you don't typically eat much you may be able to split one.  If you eat a lot and have a friend I highly recommend splitting a deluxe falafel and the schwarma of the day (they either offer lamb or chicken depending on the day of the week).  

Upside:
Possibly the greatest schwarma or falafel wraps of your life... seriously amazing.

Downside:
There is no place to sit (well, there are 4 bartops that you have to contend with people in line for space) so be prepared to take it to go.
author: Bryce G.

description:
So I have to agree with Danny P. below. Maybe I just came in with ridiculous expectations, but I wasn't blown away at all. 

Don't get me wrong... the food was good (and the shwarmas were big), but I doubt I'd trek to the Mission again for them.
author: Tanaya P.

description:
Pretty delicious and easy to eat, especially for something quick, tasty, and fairly healthy on the go. On my walk home from work its sometimes hard to walk by, and always a good choice if I am on my way somewhere and just need to grab a meal to eat on BART (shhh!) or in a car or something.

Also, the guys who work here are friendly and great if they aren't too busy taking tons of orders.
author: Gregory P.

description: Worth the trip from anywhere on a Tuesday or Friday for Chicken Shawerma, the rest of the week, have the Lamb Shawerma and a Ginger Beer.
author: Mark W.

description: after being disappointed by Picarro across the street, we headed here for some real food. Got the chicken kabob as always. The workers are really friendly and know how to put together a good gyro. Thanks again!
author: Beach L.

description: This place is solid.  About $7 bucks for a wrap - I like the lamb schwarma and the falafel one. Great sauce - nice and spicy, but not enough to burn your eyebrows off.  The staff is funny and the place is easy-going and clean.  Tiny, so not the place you wanna bring a date, but great location -  go to grab some food and then head home.
author: Kamael S.

description:
I don't particularly like Mediterranean food. I find it dry, acidic and often quite bland.

I thought I didn't like *any* Mediterranean food until I visited L'As du Falafel in Paris and had, for the first time ever, an incredibly enjoyable falafel.

So I decided that there must be a good falafel in San Francisco. Truly Mediterranean isn't quite it. The ingredients were good, but I just didn't really taste anything. Eventually the spicy sauce they put on it hit my tongue, but it just seemed... bland. Maybe the flavor is too subtle for me to pick up. Still I couldn't help thinking the whole time that a bit of salt would really bring out the flavor.

Now mind you that I finished the huge falafel off, but it just wasn't quite what I was looking for.
author: Jordan M.

description: Most definitely one of my must-haves when visiting The City is a falafel deluxe!  I have been frequenting this establishment for almost 10 years and the quality of their food has never wavered.  I truly believe that one cannot go wrong with anything on their menu!
author: Edel H.

description:
Best. Drunk. Food. Ever. 

Lamb Shawarma it up with some potato!
author: Ramin R.

description:
The falafel's pretty good, messy, but good. Odd how it always gets all-over the table and my shirt but yet the falafel itself is kind of dry.  I think this is the only Mediterranean spot I know where I feel super full and bloated after.  Normally I would feel extra healthy when I eat Mediterranean food, but not here. 

Regardless, the place is yummy.
+3.5 

ps--this review makes me sound like a complete slob.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
I had a kefta kabab sandwich which was pretty damn awesome.  It took a really long time (15 minutes) for them to prepare it but it was worth it.  It's kinda different eating falafels in lavash as opposed to pita but I liked the crispy texture.  It was tasty, spicy (but not too spicy) and really huge.  Can't beat that for $6.

The place is really small, has a counter and a couple tables outside, that's about it.
author: Shyam P.

description:
High three, but still a three.  Was good, but not great, and certainly not knock our socks off.  Pretty sure there are better options for mediterranean fare in the city.

Shawarma sandwich was good, hummus was pretty saucy and spilled all over the place.  Next time I'd go for the falafel instead.
author: Jenny S.

description:
I went there twice and got falafel both times.  The place was okay but the food was colder than it should be.  Took a pretty long time.  I would say got to El Cumbre down the street to get a falafel burrito.

I lived in Germany for a year and the Donner Kebab and Gyro places kicked this place's butt.
author: Andre G.

description: This place makes the BEST Chicken Shawerma I have EVER had! It is worth the close to 9 dollars and then some. I order mine with no onions... I am allergic... and EXTRA hot sauce. I have no idea what the sauce is made with but it is the best hot sauce/paste EVER!!!! They only make chicken on Tuesdays and Fridays... and I reserve 1 day a month to get one.  I can't say enough on how good these are... even the tomatoes are nice and firm. It is a no frills place... just get your food and eat it on a stool our on some plastic chairs outside. You can always get it to go... but I can't wait that long to eat it!
author: Amelia M.

description: Chicken shawerma wasn't as awesome but still decent.  Stick to the lamb, IMHO.
author: Desmo K.

description:
Okay, so what if the eggplant in the Falafel Deluxe makes me sick after eating about half the wrap?  It was good as hell during the first half!  

Seriously, the potatoes in the Falafel Deluxe just made it so fucking delicious, I don't even know how to explain it.  The ingredients in the wrap were just so comforting.  Yeah, it got kind of heavy towards the end, but I don't care, I enjoyed it until I got full. 

Sometimes, I hate myself for not being able to eat a lot.  COME ON ANNA, STEP IT UP!  I ate about 3/4 of the wrap, but I wanted to eat more.  

My friend got their Sirloin patty in a pita pocket.  She said it was really good, so that's what I'm getting next time!  I can't wait to go back there!
author: Anna T.

description: Yowza!! How delicious! I was not looking forward to going to Dolores Park, but this pit stop for take out to enjoy in the sun made it all worth the trek from the East Bay. I generally don't like yogurt sauces and this...this was so gooood. I couldn't stop drizzling it all over my wrap, my boyfriend's wrap...the lamb was amazing....ugh....now I'm hungry.
author: Chia C.

description:
yummy and cheap! their hummus is very tasty. Love the feta sandwich. 
Only a few seats inside at the counter and maybe one or two tables outside, so be prepared to get it to go.
author: Veena S.

description:
I have had the pleasure of enjoying Truly Mediterranean's shawermas and falafel deluxes for about 8 years now.  The service is fast and always with a smile.  The food is absolutely awesome, especially on Tuesdays and Fridays when they have chicken shawermas!

My sister's in the air force and has served time in the middle east.  She got to taste the authentic food first hand, and still raves about Truly Mediterranean's delicious bites.  She makes it a point to stop by there whenever she visits.
author: madonna u.

description:
One of the few top Falafel places in the city....

grab a falafel deluxe and walk or ride to delores...

well worth it!!!
author: Sharif R.

description: Mmmmmm!!! Chicken shawarma is the best. Grab one to go and take a walk around the mission! They are huge!
author: Mike S.

description:
I feel that hummus should be part of any wrap, like beans on a burrito.  

I found out the hard way that this is not the case at Truly Med.  Mid-order I tried to add hummus, and they reprimanded me for not asking earlier, even when I admitted that I assumed it came on the wrap.  

No offer to make a new one.  Customer service sucked, at least on that occasion.

I won't be back.  Ali Baba is my official neighborhood falafel place.
author: Aimee B.

description:
I walked in and I knew this was the one.  The obligatory spinning spit of meat was there.  I made eye contact with guy at the counter and he said NEXT.  No small talk, no friendly greetings.  I wasn't sure, I was saying "uhh, uhh, lamb sharma".  He nodded and yelled NEXT.

When I got my wrap, it was without a doubt my favorite Mediterranean experience so far.  I got my food immediately, it was portable, it was hot, and it was filled with MEAT.  Juicy, oh so juicy.
author: Jerry C.

description: Truly Med rules. Super fresh and perfectly filling. Get the lamb shawarma with extra babaghanoush and a little spicy and you can not go wrong.
author: Kenny S.

description: BOMB ASS Shawermas!  I always try to get some when im in the area. But make sure you dont have a date later on that night because you will have onion breath. The sucky part is when you can't find any parking.
author: MENG D.

description: Read rave reviews about this place prior to leaving for a vacation to San Francisco, so I made a mental note to check it out once I was in town. Best spicy lamb shawerma ever. End of story. Makes me sad there's not a Truly Mediterranean in Vegas.
author: Megan O.

description: Deluxe falafel wrap--exceptional. Been consistently good all three times I've visited.
author: Joshua S.

description:
It started many years ago... my love affair with Truly.  They used to have a location in upper Haight that was lively and welcoming.  The food, as always is out -of- this- world good!! 

Every person that i bring here is hooked.  My one warning, which seems to be common... its gonna get messy.  Be prepared with lots o napkins, extra shirts and breathe mints.
author: Anne K.

description: Good but nothing that left me craving more. I was bummed they only serve chicken shawarma on tues and friday - we went on a monday so no luck for me. We got the lamb shwarma since it was on the big eats list and some other wrap thing, their version of a burger and it was ok. Could have been quite a bit spicier and we asked for the spicy sauce but it was just ok.
author: Audrey V.

description: I went with the Chicken Kabob, it was ok, but nothing like the Chicken Shawerma which is only aviailable on Tues and Fridays. Im still giving the spot a 4 star since Ive been there so many times and consistantly have great meals.
author: Schmitty G.

description:
A friend and i went to Truly Mediterranean one night to try it out since we were in the neighborhood.  

this is what we ordered:

Falafe was alright, (a little too dry) 

combo plate was not bad (all veggies), hummus needed some more garlic  

we also got the lamb shawerma, which was the best of all 3!  

why 3 stars??  i had better mediterranean food made from someone else.  

Overall, its an OKAY restaurant O YEAH, TAKE IT TO-GO only!!!
author: Anna W.

description: Still a very good lamb schawerma with lots of meat filling, onions and peppers. Having been here a few times in the past, I always enjoy the very friendly service and nice people preparing the food in front of you, even gave us a sample of their excellent falafel to sample!! Will order the falafel next time I'm here.
author: Wolfy W.

description: Great schwarma and falafel wraps, I definitely prefer the traditional lamb schwarma to the chicken (they switch it up every few days).  Good prices, fast, and pretty close to Dolores for a picnic
author: K J.

description: Small little gem, every single time i'm around I have to go there.  The thing to order here is plain and simple.  Falafel Wrap, yes the shawarma is good and the chicken might be ok but the falafel's is what keeps most people back.  If you like spicy bring your own because they have a spicy sauce thats a joke.   You can add feta cheese to any wrap for a $1.
author: Albert G.

description:
Had one of the cheaper meat/sausage wraps.  So, I will re-assess with the Kebab or Falaffel...but the newspaper clippings & Truly Med's hole-in-the-wall atmosphere made me hope for "the best".  And my wrap was...well..good.  
3-stars of disappointment.
author: Robby T.

description: The lamb shawerma is the best I've ever had.  The first time I had it I only ate half because it just looks huge, but every time after I can't help myself from eating it all.  My mouth is watering writing this review.....if only my stomach is bigger so I can eat more....
author: Mai-Tam N.

description:
I'm not sure why people give this place a good rating as their falafels are in my mind bland and overpriced when compared to Ali Baba's cave and other locations in the Mission.

Edit: I need to go back for the Chicken or Lamb Shawarma.
author: Anthony K.

description:
I like Truly Mediterranean a lot, I always have, I just don't go there very often.

It's probably the combination of associating the Mission with burritos, the parking, and the clowns asking for money while I try to eat a falafel. 

Anyway, I think they're really good, right up there with Mediterranean Spirit and Sunrise Deli. 

They'd probably be the best if there was somewhere to sit. Love that hot sauce.

Ali Baba's Cave, you're dead to me.
author: Jason R.

description: I came year yesterday and had the Falafel Deluxe, I think it was supposed to have eggplant in it, but either they forgot to put it in, or it was such a small amount I couldn't tell. There was french fries in it I think..unless that was the eggplant?  I liked it, it was good.  A little too saucy, but tasted good.  This is only the 2nd Falafel wrap I've ever had it was different it had cucumbers in it instead of lettuce, was a bit heavier, but over all delish. Quick Tip: If this is going to be your first time there, be aware that the place is small.  Only a long table against the wall with bar stools, and outside there are 2 wobbly tables and plastic grimey chairs. We came here with our baby in a stroller and had to eat outside, and it was windy and cold. So plan accordingly.
author: Charla M.

description: I had the chicken shawerma and I thought it tasted a little dry.  The combo plate with falafel, hummus, cheese, and etc. was good but I have a buddy who's parents cook this stuff and it's better homemade.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Shwarmas tend to be filling and moderately tasty, but a kabob I had featured not-so-tender meat and not all that much flavor.

And sadly, nothing compares to the doener kebabs I had in Germany:  such juicy, melt-in-your-mouth meat with an amazing garlic sauce... [sigh].
author: Adam L.

description:
Shwarma! Shwarma! Shwarma! 

Truly good Shwarma at Truly Mediterranean. Truly. 

Mmm... 

Great. Now I'm hungry.
author: Jessica D.

description:
Stripped down, almost utilitarian culinary rock and rai. Lucky I passed by on a Friday 'cause it was chicken shewarma day and g-damnfuck was it good (love the hot sauce), and held me for hours. Fresh squeezed carrot juice. 

The tough lass that works the register is sweet; she brought my carrot juice. I love middle eastern food and their falafel, hummus, dolmas etc. are great but well be shore to calm bakk on thair she-warma dais. I was going to ask the owner about the nationalities of the singers whose cds he sells (he sells cds!)  but I didn't. Next time. I should be up on my Arabic pop. Shukran.

Natural light: Good
author: Mark G.

description:
I went here a few weeks ago expecting great things based on all the positive yelp reviews, and I'm not going to lie, I really wasn't that impressed.  The falafel was really good, with just the right spices, crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside.  But as we all know, a falafel platter is made or broken based on its sides - and those of Truly Mediterranean just didn't quite cut it.  There was the right combo of dolmas, hummus, baba ganoush and tabouli, but everything was a little off, either too salty (baba) or sweet (dolmas) or drippy (hummus) or dry (pita).  I don't want to be a hater, but after my expectations were built up, my taste buds were sorely disappointed.

Truly Med, maybe I'll give you a chance to redeem yourself, but you better not let me down again.
author: Rachel B.

description:
I resigned myself to mediocre felafel. It's true. I was convinced that I'd never have a tasty falefel in San Francisco, ever. I thank the goddess that I found Truly Mediterranean.

I've only had a regular felafel here and have to say it's exactly what I want/need from a felafel. It's crispy, chewy and  jucy all at the same time. 

Tips for Truly Mediterranean are:
1. Get your food to go
2. Know what you want before you get in line
3. Don't expect the staff to kiss your ass, they don't care if you live or die.
author: Ricky J.

description:
Falafel all day, falafel all night.

This place is the best. Their falafels are really really good. Go falafel supreme and you're bound to have the best day every. It includes the standard delicious veggie balls but they add eggplant and fries. I would recommend getting some of their shwarma sauce (maybe tahini?) to dump on it because they can get a little dry.

If you're not in the falafel mood, go for the mediterranean platter. Dolmas, hummus, babaganoush, cucumber salad, feta and tebouleh (a little heavy on the parsley at times). It's a wonderful veggie treat.

And then if you want to go big, the shwarma is giant and delicious.
author: C P.

description:
Yum Yum Yum Yum Yum Yum Yum Yum Yummy!
I love this place along with the one or two older men behind the counter.  I get cravings for the schwarma there (lamb and/or chicken, maybe both!)...Order it spicy with everything but light on the onions because those onions they use are POTENT!

You will not be kissing anyone after this.
author: Shannon B.

description:
I was introduced to this place by my best friend when I first moved to the bay area, and I've been going back ever since (5 years now!). I've tried the hummus, dolma and feta wraps. I've also had their tabbouleh, babaganoush, and tzatziki. I think my favorite is the dolma wrap. I love dolma, so it really just adds a great flavor to the wrap. The only downside to this place is that their menu is quite limited. It's very basic Mediterranean fast food. This is also coming from a very picky vegetarian, so ignore my biased opinion on that point. 

The place is very small, so I suggest ordering to go. Its definitely worth the money and the trip to the mission for a tasty meal.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I was hankering for some falafel in class this morning, so I thought I'd drop by on the way home.

First thing I noticed about the falafel was its price! $5.80 (after tax) for a falafel? The storied Mamouns by NYU in NYC has great falafel, and it is almost half the price ($2.95 before tax). Let's not condemn prematurely though. As the 'chef' was preparing my falafel, I understood why there is high entry price. This isn't your regular falafel pita- it is wrapped in a burrito-large lavash pita with falafel balls, hot sauce (by request), the usual vegetable medley, and plenty of tahini sauce. So consider it a burrito of sorts - one falafel from Truly Med is at least 1.5 Mamoun's falafels.

So how did it taste? It was good but didn't bowl me over.  The falafels were not greasy but were a bit bland, and though the hot sauce added some kick, the tahini was not as savory as I liked it. The vegetable medley was great though - the cucumbers, onions, etc., added a fresh crunchiness. I also must commend the structural integrity of the falafel sandwich. Most of the time I have major problems keeping my lap clean when eating a falafel sandwich - the combination of drippy tahini and crumbliness of the falafel balls usually spells doom. Not so with with 'falafel burrito' - the experience was generally clean, and while there was of course some dripping and flinging, the falafel did not collapse until the latter portions of my meal. All in all, not a bad meal, but I've had better falafel in SFC (try Kan Zaman in the Haight).
author: Susheel D.

description:
My favorite mediterranean restaurant in the bay area. It's open late enough so you can order a Falafel with spicy sauce and a couple of dolmas to get you through the hangover you have from the many bars in the Mission area club scene any night of the week. In the past twelve years they've gone through several waves of staff, some of them pleasant, some of them not so pleasant, but always more interesting than the yuppies who also frequent the area and take over on the weekends.
Every time I come back to visit San Francisco, probably once a year, this establishment is always on my list of must-eat places to go to.
author: Sam A.

description:
I to go this place way more than a sane person should.  Its not very conveniently located for me, I don't like the neighborhood much anymore and you pretty much have to expect to NOT dine in.  But I'll be damned if I don't admit that they have some of the best falafels in the city(Mediterranean Spirit R.I.P.).  I can also recommend the chicken shwerma and be able to sleep at night.  It kind of rules.

CONCLUSION:

Do you know what certainly does not rule?  YOUR FACE!  You look like something that fell out of an elephants back end and your breath smells like something that fell out of my back end after 7 consecutive thanksgiving dinners featuring turkey deep-fried in goat lard.
author: ray M.

description:
Great veggie food! We ordered their large veggie platters for a party and they were a huge success! The baba ghanoush and hummus are great and the felafel went so fast! It also comes with tahini, tabouli, feta cheese, and delicious dolmas. We highly recommend this place for vegetarians (and everyone else!)

Unfortunately they do not have whole wheat pita bread...
author: Veg V.

description: Pretty decent shawerma, but they're nearly $10. Not worth it.
author: Brian C.

description: They sell tasty falafels at a relatively inexpensive rate. They're also very filling.  The only thing bad about this place is that it's so small, so if it's busy you might actually have to wait outside.  Sitting in front of a mirror while you eat to a tiny stool is never very fun.  Go here for the food though, it's worth it, especially if you're looking for a quick, filling bite to eat.  I want to try their baklava one day.  Yummy.
author: Amy J.

description: Love hummus and lamb schwarma.
author: Jim J.

description: I really like this place and think their food is super tasty, but I can't stand the fact that they have their meat so close to the door and with no barrier from their customers.  Last time I was here a nasty girl (customer) touched the meat spinner and I was so grossed out.  I only come here for falafel and their garlic yogurt drink now.  I really wish they would add some sort of shield to protect their cooked meats from people...they would totally get a 5 star rating from me then!!
author: Kevin M.

description:
Great cheap Mediterranean street food.

In homage to Mediterranean street vendors, this place serves a small taste of that flavor.  This place is always there for all of the lovely Mission dwellers.  A great grab-and-go spot.  The Gyros have so much flavor, and can get a bit on the messy side.  I usually would get their Lamb Shawarma; which I impulsively would gravitate toward whenever here.  I do love their Hummus too: rich, creamy, and fresh. The place offers great and quick street food that's worth stopping by for.

An array of tasty dishes, for cheap prices, all in one place.
author: Satoru Y.

description:
I don't think I had even stepped foot into Truly Med until a band of fellow rabble-rousers introduced me to the place.  

We had just finished a meeting to begin organizing against Clinton's sanctions on Iraq.  (The sanctions were bad enough.  I don't think we could have imagined what Iraq would experience next.)

Most of our group was Arab-American, and I followed them around the corner to the favored destination.  I knew I'd be a repeat customer.
author: Sanjeev B.

description: Falafel Deluxe add feta and hot sauce
author: J W.

description: Love this place! A little hole in the wall, but the lamb Shwarma is to die for. Despite the awful parking situation, I go the distance to visit this place. My daughter loves it too and its a favorite spot that we have shared together since she was a little girl.
author: l t.

description:
It's fine.  

It's rare that I get in the mood for falafel, but today I had to do it and I went here.  I got the Super Deluxe... and should have known by the name.
